He led the Woodmen north to join the fight against Thangorodrim, and he was recognized with honor by the Elves. When large numbers of Orcs began to appear, Halmir sent for the aid of Elu Thingol of Doriath. To Halmir was sent a host of the Sindar under Beleg Cúthalion, and the combined force of the Woodmen and Sindar ambushed and destroyed an orc-legion in the depths of the forest; in this way Halmir won renown.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd8891] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Hareth lived during the First Age of Middle-earth, and was the elder daughter of Halmir, the Chieftain of the Haladin, and sister of Haldir, Hundar, and Hiril. She married Galdor in FA 436 of Dor-lómin, Lord of the House of Hador, and bore him two sons, Húrin and Huor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: He became Chieftain of the Haladin in Brethil for a time in his adulthood. He married Glóredhel of the House of Hador at the same feast where Galdor married Hareth, and they had a son named Handir. He fostered Húrin and Huor in their childhood years. Haldir marched with the rest of his kin in support of the Union of Maedhros and was slain in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad along with most of the Men of Brethil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd8891] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Hiril was a woman of the Haladin, the younger daughter of Halmir of Brethil and sister of Haldir of Brethil, Hareth and Hundar.She was the wife of a man called Enthor and by him mother of a girl called Meleth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Hundar was the youngest son of Halmir, and his siblings were Haldir, Hareth, and Hiril. He had a daughter named Hunleth and a son named Hundad. Little else of his life is known, save that he perished in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Handir was born in the year 441 of the First Age. He was said to be a great warrior, and served as chieftain and Lord of the Men of Brethil around the time of the Nírnaeth Arnoediad. During his lordship, Orcs invaded his lands, and leading the fight against them, he was slain in battle north of the Forest of Brethil. His people were driven back into the woods.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd8891] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Meleth was the child of Hiril and Enthor. She was the wife of Agathor, to whom she bore Manthor and Hunthor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Hundad was a man of the House of Haleth in the First Age. His father was Hundar, and his son was Hardang, who became Chieftain of Brethil during the later life of Húrin Thalion.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Brandir was born in FA 465 to Handir and Beldis who was a woman of the House of Bëor. Brandir was lamed by a leg broken in a misadventure in childhood. His disability resulted the appellations 'The Lame' and 'Clubfoot' being attached to his name. The latter was an insult used by Túrin during his confrontation with Brandir following Niënor's death. Brandir was a man of gentle mood, lover of plants and skilled healer. He was against open war with the Orcs because he hoped to preserve his people by silence and secrecy.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd8891] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Hunthor was a member of the Second House of the Edain and resided in Brethil during the years his kinsman Brandir the Lame was Lord. Hunthor was an adventurous fellow who befriended Turin Turambar and accompanied him on his quest to slay the Dragon Glaurung. Hunthor's decision enraged Brandir and caused many of his fellow Haladin to question Brandir's rule. Hunthor never returned, however, for during his attempt to climb in the gorge of Cabed-en-Aras and quietly stalk the Drake, he was hit by a falling rock and fell to his death.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: He ran for Chieftain of the Men of Brethil against Hardang, because Manthor was related to Brandir the Lame, the previous Halbar of the Haladin, and Manthor thought that he could win by his noble blood, as Brandir was his second-cousin. However, Manthor was related to Brandir through Halmir's daughter Hiril, who was the grandmother of Manthor and the sister of Halmir's son Haldir, who in turn was the grandfather of Brandir. This meant that Manthor's kinship with Brandir was worth less in the eyes of the people of Haleth, and he lost the election.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: After the death of the Halbar of Brethil, Handir, Hardang tried to supersede his cousin, Brandir, in acquiring the leadership of the Men of Brethil. Many Haladin believed Brandir to be unfit to rule them, and therefore supported Hardang. Many people wanted Brandir's cousin Manthor to assume the role of Halbar instead. Unfortunately for him and his supporters, he was related to Brandir by a daughter, which meant that his kinship with Brandir was worth less in the eyes of the people. Hardang then won the vote, and became the Halbar of the Men of Brethil in FA 499.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd8891]

lotr_info.info: Marach and his people crossed the Blue Mountains into Beleriand during the First Age after the Bëorians and the Haladin. The House of Marach became the Third House of the Edain and later the title of that house was more commonly known as the House of Hador. The People of Marach were great in number, and Bëor described them as warlike, marching in ordered companies; and the Green Elves did not hinder their arrival in Ossiriand.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Malach was the eldest son of Marach, the first chieftain of his people who were numerous compared to the other houses of the Edain. The House of Marach was the Third House of the Edain. When they crossed the Blue Mountains into Beleriand, Malach dwelt at first with his people at Estolad, but later journeyed north and entered the service of the Ñoldorin Elven-prince Fingon, son of the High Elven-king Fingolfin of the Ñoldor in Hithlum.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Imlach was born in the early fourth century of the First Age to Marach. His brother was Malach. Little to nothing is known about his life save that he was married and was the father of Amlach.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Zimrahin was the wife of Malach, whom she wedded in the year FA 337. After their marriage, she took the elvish name Meldis. She bore Malach a daughter, Adanel, in FA 339, and a son, Magor, two years later.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Adanel was a wise woman of the House of Marach. She was a daughter of Malach and Zimrahin, and the older sister of Magor. Adanel had many other brothers and sisters as well, and, like Magor her brother, they may have been younger than she.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: It was told that Magor was known as the 'Sword', and later his son Hathol was called the 'Axe'. He was of the House of Marach, the third and greatest house of the Edain.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Amlach was the son of Imlach and the grandson of Marach[1], the leader of the third host of men to enter Beleriand. Originally, he did not trust the Elves, and was the leader of dissension among the Men of Estolad. Later on, he repented and entered into the service of Maedhros.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: The fair-haired son of Magor Dagorlind, Hathol was an Adan Warrior, the Lord of Dor-lómin, and chief among the Edain of the Third House. Hathol was the grandson of the original Lord, Malach Aradan, and he was the father of Hador Lórindol.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Hador Goldenhead, known also as Hador Lórindol, was a great chieftain of the Edain in the First Age of Middle-earth, and a revered Edain among many of the greatest Elf-friends of the Eldar. He became the first Lord of Dor-lómin and was accounted mighty even among the Eldar.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Gildis was a noble woman of the House of Hador. She was of the progeny of Ermon and mother of Galdor the Tall and Glóredhel of Brethil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Glóredhel was the daughter of Hador and Gildis, and was the eldest sister of Galdor and Gundor. She married Haldir, Chieftain of the Haladin, and soon gave birth to Handir. In FA 472, Haldir was killed in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad, causing Glóredhel to die of grief shortly afterwards.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Galdor was noted for his exceptional height, even among the Edain, and was thus called Galdor the Tall. He led the people of Hador during the peak of their power, before the Dagor Bragollach. He was slain by an arrow seven years after that battle, when the Barad Eithel was besieged by Morgoth's armies.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: In the year 458 of the First Age Huor and Húrin dwelt with their kin in the forest of Brethil, when they joined a war party against Orcs. The brothers ended up in the Vale of Sirion, and were cut off from their company. Chased by Orcs, the Vala Ulmo caused a mist to arise from the rivers, and the brothers escaped into Dimbar. There two Eagles picked them up, and brought them to Gondolin.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Húrin, known also as Húrin Thalion or once Úmarth, was a hero of Men during the First Age. He was the father of the tragic Túrin Turambar. According to The Silmarillion, he was the greatest warrior of Men in the First Age.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Tuor was born in FA 472 after the Nírnaeth Arnoediad, in which his father Huor died. After hearing that the battle was lost, Rían fell into despair and left Dor-lómin while still pregnant with Tuor. She would have been lost and died if not for the Sindar Elves of Mithrim who rescued her and took her to their home in the Mountains of Mithrim. Tuor was soon born and first fostered by the Grey-elves. Later, their leader Annael told his mother that Huor had perished in the battle. She soon fell into grief in her early twenties and went to Haudh-en-Ndengin, the Hill of the Slain and seeing the mounds of rotting and despoiled remains, she fell sick and died.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Nienor, also called Níniel, was Húrin and Morwen's third child, the sister of Túrin Turambar. She was born in Hithlum in the year of Nírnaeth Arnoediad. After this battle, the Easterlings settled in the land and oppressed the people of Hador.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: He had a younger sister Urwen, whom everyone called 'Lalaith' because of her laughter. Urwen was loved more than Túrin, who did not speak often and seemed older than his years. However, she died in childhood of a plague and Morwen forbade Túrin from speaking Urwen's nickname. Túrin became a close friend of Sador the one-legged carpenter, whom he named Labadal ('hop-a-foot'). On the morning of Túrin's eighth birthday, his father gave him an Elf-wrought knife, but he gave it to Sador. After Húrin was captured in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad, Túrin remained with his mother Morwen, who hid him from the Easterlings that Morgoth had sent to Hithlum, fearing they would kill Túrin or enslave him. Unknown to Túrin at that time, Morgoth had placed a curse on all of Húrin's family.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fcd317] via-[#08e2fe] to-[#fcd317]

lotr_info.info: Urwen was nicknamed Lalaith, because her laughter was compared to the merry sound of the Nen Lalaith,[6] a stream from Amon Darthir that ran by the walls of Húrin's house in Dor-lómin, because she was a happy child and brought much joy to the hearts of the household of Húrin during her short life. Her hair was yellow like the lilies that grew in the grass fields of Dor-lómin. She often took to 'going upon grass or under tree', singing old songs from long ago that were made when the Edain first learned 'the tongue of the Elves'. It was because of this that Húrin once said to Morwen that Urwen was as 'fair as an Elf-child…but briefer'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Indor was an Edain man of Dor-lómin, possibly of some importance. He and his daughter Aerin were closely related to Húrin Thalion. His fate is unknown, but he was presumed dead by FA 495 when Túrin, the son of Húrin, returned to Dor-lómin.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: Aerin was the daughter of Indor, who was closely related to Húrin Thalion of the House of Hador. When the treacherous Easterlings invaded Hithlum as payment for fighting on Morgoth's side in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad, Aerin was cruelly seized by Brodda. He took her as his wife against her will, hoping to produce an heir to legitimize his rule as Lord of Hithlum. Aerin secretly helped Húrin's wife Morwen and sheltered Sador, the former servant of Húrin and childhood friend of Túrin.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#d8e28b]

lotr_info.info: In the Year of the Sun 463 of the First Age, when eight years had passed since the Dagor Bragollach, Bór led his people into Lothlann, and these Easterlings were worthy folk and tillers of the earth.[2] Bór had three sons named Borlad, Borlach, and Borthand, and they were welcomed by Maedhros the eldest son of Fëanor, who gave Bór and his followers land north of the March of Maedhros, and south of it.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Ulfang was among the 'Swarthy Men' who had come out of the East into Beleriand. He swore allegiance to Caranthir but was secretly in the service of Morgoth. In the battle his men turned on the Sons of Fëanor. Their force, which was being attacked on three sides, was dissipated, allowing Morgoth to concentrate his forces on Fingon and Turgon. Ulfang's treacherous progeny, however, paid for their betrayal with their lives, for Uldor, Ulfast, and Ulwarth all perished in the battle.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Borlach was an Easterling Man from Lothlann, alive during the late First Age. He was the son of Bór and fought with the Union of Maedhros at the Nírnaeth Arnoediad. Like his father and his two brothers Borlad and Borthand, Borlach remained loyal to the Sons of Fëanor, unlike the Easterlings who followed Ulfang, who betrayed them. He was slain in the battle, while fighting against the traitors.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Borlad fought with the Union of Maedhros at the Nírnaeth Arnoediad and like his father and two brothers remained loyal to the Sons of Fëanor, unlike those of Ulfang who betrayed them. He was slain fighting against the traitors.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Borthand was an Easterling man, son of Bór, apparently the youngest of his three sons. Borthand fought with the Union of Maedhros at the Nírnaeth Arnoediad and, like his father and two brothers, remained loyal to the Sons of Fëanor, unlike those of Ulfang, who betrayed them. He was slain fighting against the traitors.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Uldor was from one of the tribes of Easterlings who entered into the service of the Sons of Fëanor. Serving with Caranthir since FA 457, Uldor and his brothers Ulfast and Ulwarth helped Caranthir prepare for war with Morgoth; but like the rest of his family, they were already secretly allied with him.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Like his father, Ulwarth entered Beleriand and pledged his service to the Sons of Fëanor. They served under Caranthir, but their only true loyalty was to Morgoth, and their purpose was to betray him at the right time. During a critical time during the Nírnaeth Arnoediad, he turned on Caranthir attacking his forces from the rear. When Bór and the other faithful Easterlings saw what they were doing, Bór and his men slew him and his father and brothers Ulfast and Uldor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Like his father, Ulwarth entered Beleriand and pledged his service to the Sons of Fëanor. They served under Caranthir, but their only true loyalty was to Morgoth, and their purpose was to betray him at the right time. During a critical time during the Nírnaeth Arnoediad, he turned on Caranthir attacking his forces from the rear. When Bór and the other faithful Easterlings saw what they were doing, Bór and his men slew him and his father and brothers Ulfast and Uldor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Ulfast was one of the three sons of Ulfang. He followed his father in the Nírnaeth Arnoediad where they betrayed the host of Caranthir. He was killed by the sons of Bór for he and his father's treachery against Caranthir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Brodda was a chief of those Easterlings in league with Morgoth in the First Age. After the Battle of Unnumbered Tears, their master sent them to Hithlum, 'to plunder and harass' what remained of the House of Hador. With Húrin imprisoned in Angband, Brodda usurped the lordship of Dor-lómin and also forcefully wedded Aerin, a kinswoman of Húrin, to try legitimize his rule. After Morwen's flight, he seized the opportunity to claim the rest of Húrin's possessions.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#000000] via-[#c1a55b] to-[#000000]

lotr_info.info: Vardamir was heir to the Kingship of Númenor, noted as an exceptional scholar whose only desire was to study, not to rule. When Elros died, Vardamir immediately abdicated in favour of his son, Tar-Amandil. He was counted as the second King of Númenor, having nominally ruled for a single year. He died in year 471 of the Second Age, aged 410 years. If Vardamir was a Half-elf, he therefore chose a mortal fate.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tindómiel was the second child and only daughter of Elros Tar-Minyatur, Half-elf and the first King of Númenor. She was born after SA 61 and was the sister of Manwendil, Atanalcar, and the short reigning King Vardamir Nólimon. Nothing else is known of her life or whether she married and had children.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Manwëndil, was the third child and second son of Elros Tar-Minyatur. His descendants became one of the leading families of Arandor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Atanalcar was born after SA 61 and was the younger brother of Manwendil, Tindómiel, and the short reigning king Vardamir Nólimon. Nothing else is known of his life only that he was possibly married and had children.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Amandil was actually Númenor's second ruler; his father, Vardamir Nólimon, had declined to take the throne upon the death of his own father, Elros Tar-Minyatur. He abdicated due to advanced age in favor of his son Tar-Amandil but was still by right of succession the ruler, and Vardamir is still counted in the list of kings, making him the second king. Thus, Tar-Amandil was listed as the third King of Númenor. As Vardamir was potentially Half-elven like Elros, Tar-Amandil may have been a Half-elf of the third generation, giving him a slow maturity and long youth like the Elves, while being fated for mortality like Men.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Vardilmë was born in Númenor in an unknown location. Her father Vardamir was potentially Half-elven like her grandfather Elros, the first King of Númenor. This means she may have been a Half-elf of the third generation, giving her a slow maturity and long youth like the Elves, while being fated for mortality like Men.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Aulendil was the second son and third child of Tar-Vardamir, second king of Númenor. He was a famous smith and artificer, and as prince of Andúnie a member of the Crown Council.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Nolondil was a numenorean prince, the fourth child and second son of King Tar-Vardamir.He was brother of Vardilme, Aulendil of Andúnië and Tar-Amandil and father of Yavien, Oromendil and Axantur, the ancestor of the rulers of Hyarastorni.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Elendil was the direct ancestor of all subsequent Kings of Númenor through his son. From the time of the reign of Tar-Elendil, the Númenóreans began to make voyages to Middle-earth. It was in SA 600 that Vëantur, the Captain of the King's Ships, sailed from Númenor to Middle-earth for the first time. He surrendered the Sceptre in SA 740 and died in the year 751 of the Second Age, at the age of 401.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Vëantur was the Númenórean captain of the royal fleet of Tar-Elendil. He was likewise grandfather of Tar-Aldarion. Vëantur was also the commander of the first ship that returned to Middle-earth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Mairen was the third child and the only daughter of the third Númenórean King, Tar-Amandil, and sister to the future King, Tar-Elendil. Virtually nothing is known about her life but that she had one other brother, Eärendur.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: He was the younger son of Tar-Amandil, the third King of Númenor. He had a son, Caliondo, who in turn had a son, Malantur. Malantur was apparently a possible heir to Tar-Aldarion, his cousin, but the law was changed such that Aldarion's daughter Ancalimë would be the heir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Born in an unknown location in Númenor, Yávien was the first child and only daughter of Nolondil, the youngest son of the short-reigning King Vardamir Nólimon. She had two siblings (brothers), the younger being Axantur and the older being Oromendil. Her uncle Amandil would take the Sceptre as Tar-Amandil, third King of Númenor. Nothing else is known of her life, including whether she married and had children.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Oromendil was the first son and the second child of Nolondil. He had two siblings: Yávien, his older sister and Axantur, his younger brother. Nothing else is known of his life.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Axantur was the son of Nolondil and the cousin of King Tar-Elendil. He had two other siblings: Yávien and Oromendil. He married an unnamed woman and had three children named Lindissë, Ardamir, and Cemendur. Little of Axantur's life is known; but his descendants would enter into the ruling line, and his great-grandson Hallacar would marry Tar-Ancalimë, the first Ruling Queen of Númenor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Elatan's descendants would figure prominently in the history of Middle-earth. After the Downfall of Númenor, Elendil, the last Lord of Andúnië, would found the Kingdoms of Arnor and Gondor. Thousands of years later, Elatan's descendant Aragorn II Elessar, would be a hero of the War of the Ring.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Silmariën was the oldest child of King Tar-Elendil. Her other siblings were Isilmë and Irimon. Women were not allowed to rule at the time of her father, so when Tar-Elendil relinquished the Sceptre, she was passed over for the throne in favor of her younger brother, Tar-Meneldur. After her marriage with Elatan, they had a son named Valandil who became the first Lord of Andúnië.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Hatholdir was a man descended from the House of Hador. His was a close personal friend of King Tar-Meneldur. He married an unnamed woman and had a son named Orchaldor who entered royal line through marriage with Ailinel, the oldest daughter of his father's friend.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Isilmë was a numenorean Princess, the daughter of Tar-Elendil and sister of Silmariën of Andúnië and Tar-Meneldur.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Meneldur, also known as Elentirmo and Irimon, was the fifth King of Númenor. His two older sisters were Silmariën and Isilmë. During his time the Númenóreans began to return to Middle-earth, and great fleets of ships were built to explore all the lands east of Númenor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: She cared little for ships and the sea, though her father was a great sailor. She married and gave birth to a son, Aldarion, who soon desired to follow in the footsteps of her father, Vëantur. This later displeased his father, who wanted him to marry and settle down. However, Almarian supported her son in everything he did and later served as a mediator between her husband and their son on matters regarding his life choices. She was a woman of exceptional beauty.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: A Númenórean from Andustar in western Númenor, Beregar was the father of Erendis. He traced his ancestry through the First House of the Edain (the House of Bëor), although he was not of the line of Elros.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Caliondo was born to Eärendur and his unnamed wife in a unknown place in Númenor. Caliondo had one child, a son named Malantur, the King's presumptive heir. Nothing else is known about his life.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Lindissë was the first child and daughter of Axantur and great- Aunt of Hallacar Mámandil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Ardamir was the second child and first son of Axantur and Élquassë. Married to Mëonis, he was the father of Herimacil, Liritissë, and Éldil. He was also the younger brother of Lindissë and elder brother of Cemendur.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Cemendur was the third child and son of the nobleman Axantur. He had two other siblings: Lindissë and Ardamir. He married an unnamed women and had two children named Írildë and Hallatan. His son married and had a son named Hallacar, his grandson who entered into the ruling line by marrying Tar-Ancalimë, the first Ruling Queen of Númenor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Valandil's father was Elatan of Andúnië, and his mother was Silmariën, eldest child of Tar-Elendil of Númenor. The laws of Númenor at that time would not allow Silmariën to rule as queen, so Valandil and subsequent Lords of Andúnië were not in line for royal succession. By the end of the Second Age, however, Valandil's descendants would become kings in Middle-earth, beginning with Elendil, the last Lord of Andúnië and first High King of Arnor and Gondor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#add500] via-[#b7e100] to-[#add500]

lotr_info.info: Orchaldor was a noble, son of Hatholdir a descendant of the House of Hador and a close personal friend of Tar-Meneldur. He married Ailinel the elder daughter of Tar-Meneldur and sister of Tar-Aldarion. This related him by marriage to Tar-Meneldur's heir Aldarion. He and Ailinel had a son named Soronto who should have become King but the laws of succession were changed by Tar-Aldarion that allowed his daughter to become Ruling Queen.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Ailinel was born between the years SA 700 and SA 750. Was a Princess of Númenor and the first daughter of King Tar-Meneldur and Queen Almarian, and therefore sister of Tar-Aldarion. She was the wife of Orchaldor and mother of Soronto.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Aldarion was the sixth King of Númenor, and succeeded his father, Tar-Meneldur. Tar-Aldarion was married to Erendis, a Númenórean woman, who was not a direct descendant of the house of Elros as Aldarion himself, and therefore had a shorter life-span. Aldarion's love for the sea ultimately caused a rift between the couple and they separated in SA 882. The tale of their marriage and estrangement survived the Downfall of Númenor as 'Aldarion and Erendis: The Mariner's Wife'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Erendis was born to Beregar and Núneth, who were descended from a minor branch of the Númenórean nobility descended from the House of Bëor. This was a lineage of lesser status than that of the royal house, entailing a shorter lifespan. She and her parents lived in the Númenórean region of Emerië, which she loved dearly.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Malantur was a Númenórean noble, the son of Caliondo, son of Eärendur. He lived in the late first millennium of the Second Age. Malantur was said to be the heir to his cousin the king Tar-Aldarion, but when laws were altered, the king's daughter Ancalimë became heir instead.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Írildë was the first child and only daughter of the nobleman Cemendur. She had only one sibling, a brother named Hallatan. Little of her life is known.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Hallatan was the second child and only son of Cemendur, a descendant of Vardamir Nólimon. His sister was Írildë. He owned a large amount of pastoral land in the Númenórean province of Emerië where many sheep were herded. This farming settlement was named Hyarastorni, where Hallatan ruled as 'Sheep-lord'. He often hosted Aldarion at his home in the reign of Tar-Meneldur, and where the other shepherds of Hyarastorni were known to come to visit. He was married to an unnamed woman and their children were Hallacar and Nessanië. His son came to marry Ancalimë in TA 1000.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Before the change in Númenor's law that turned the order of succession into cognatic primogeniture, Soronto may have been presumptive heir to the throne. (J.R.R. Tolkien intended to write a story about Tar-Aldarion's daughter Tar-Ancalimë and her cousin Soronto, and how she married only to prevent Soronto from inheriting the throne.)
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Ancalimë was raised by her mother Erendis, and her childhood companion was Zamîn. She moved to the Númenórean sheep-lands of Emerië where her mother had a house to escape from the many suitors who sought her hand in marriage. There she dwelt for a time, tending sheep, and assuming the name Emerwen Aranel. She received the name after she said that she could not sleep without hearing the sounds of the sheep.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Hallacar was a descendant of the short reigning king Vardamir Nólimon. He was a royal suitor who wished to marry Ancalimë, but she rejected all those who sought her hand and went into hiding in the land of Emerië.[2] He knew that Ancalimë was there and for a time he lived there as a simple shepherd, going by the name of Mámandil. The two became very close friends and frequently met with each other in the pastures. There he sang songs to her for he was quite skilled in such things and she was pleased, but he altered his songs to lament the lovers of old in an attempt to express his love for her. Afterwards, he did declare his love for her but she did not return it and drew back. It was after this that he revealed what his true name was and his lineage. Angry at this deception, she rejected him, at least at first but eventually they did agree to wed despite the fact that she did not desire to be married.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Nessanië was the first child and only daughter of Hallatan, Sheep-lord of Hyarastorni. Little to nothing is known of her life only that her brother married Ancalimë, nor is it known whether she followed her brother to Armenelos or continued living in Hyarastorni.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Ancalimë was raised by her mother Erendis, and her childhood companion was Zamîn. She moved to the Númenórean sheep-lands of Emerië where her mother had a house to escape from the many suitors who sought her hand in marriage. There she dwelt for a time, tending sheep, and assuming the name Emerwen Aranel. She received the name after she said that she could not sleep without hearing the sounds of the sheep.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Súrion had two older sisters, but they were said to have no interest in ruling; and thus he became King. In Middle-earth, the idea of the forging of the Rings of Power was born during his reign. He was succeeded by his oldest child, his daughter, Tar-Telperiën. Through his second child and oldest son Isilmo, he was grandfather to Tar-Minastir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Telperiën ruled for 175 years. During her reign, the Rings of Power were forged, and Sauron conquered Eriador. It was said that she had the powers of a magician or seer. She was asked to intervene in the War of the Elves and Sauron, but she did nothing, instead her nephew Minastir became involved and sent a fleet to Gil-Galad's aid in S.A. 1700.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Isilmo was a Man of Númenor and a prince of the House of Elros. Isilmo was the son of Tar-Súrion and the younger brother of Ruling Queen Tar-Telperiën. Tar-Telperiën outlived Isilmo but refused to wed and had no children. Thus, Tar-Telperiën was succeeded by Isilmo's son Tar-Minastir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Minastir was the son of Isilmo and succeeded his aunt, Queen Tar-Telperiën, when she died. He was the grandson of King Tar-Súrion. His heart yearned for the west as did many in his time and loved the Elves but envied them. At some point during his rule, he had a great tower built on Oromet so that he could gaze upon the west and dream.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Prior to his reign, he sailed along most of Endor's coasts, becoming acquainted with the Adan interests and colonies and satiating his restless spirit. His voyages hurt his father, who hoped that his son would remain in Westernesse and learn the crafts ascribed to an heir. When Ciryatan finally returned home, he forced his loving father to relinquish the throne prematurely. It was from this moment that the Shadow was said to have first gripped the Edain of the West.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Atanamir succeeded his father, King Tar-Ciryatan, in SA 2029. He was married to an unnamed woman and had a son named Tar-Ancalimon and another unnamed child that eventually led up to Herucalmo. Tar-Atanamir began to speak against the Valar in particular the Ban of the Valar and the Gift of Ilúvatar. He was also the first king who was unwilling to give up his throne voluntarily before his death, and to let himself die while he was still strong in mind and body. His reign is thus generally considered to constitute the beginning of Númenor's moral decline.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: During Tar-Ancalimon's reign, the people of Númenor became divided and two opposing parties arose among Númenóreans: the Elf-friends, or Elendili (also called 'The Faithful'), advocated continuing devotion to the Valar and friendship with the Elves, and the 'King's Men' who opposed the Ban of the Valar and friendship with the Elves, advocating Númenor's independence and self-determination, seeing how they had reached the apex of their might. During his time, the Elven tongues were discouraged and were no longer taught to Númenórean children. The royal titles however were still taken in Quenya out of respect for ancient customs rather than love for the Eldar. The Great Eagles which had formerly nested in an eyrie in the King's Palace in Armenelos, were no longer fed during his reign and departed. His policies would later contribute to the Fall of Númenor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Telemmaitë succeeded his father, Tar-Ancalimon. During his reign, he bade his servants to seek as much mithril as could be found. He ruled Númenor for 140 years, and was 390 when he died. His daughter, Tar-Vanimeldë, succeeded him and became Númenor's third Ruling Queen. From his time on the Kings formally held the Sceptre until they died.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Herucalmo was 'much younger' than his wife. Tar-Vanimeldë had little interest in ruling, and Herucalmo served as her regent taking over the duties of state. When she died, the throne should have gone to their son, Tar-Alcarin, but Herucalmo usurped the throne and ruled under the name Tar-Anducal ('Light of the West') from SA 2637 to SA 2657. Being an illegal claim to the throne of Númenor, Herucalmo was not recognised by historians as a rightful King of Númenor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Vanimeldë was the daughter and heir of Tar-Telemmaitë. She had little interest in ruling, loving rather culture and the arts such as music and dance, however, and left the day-to-day chores of monarchy to her husband, the nobleman Herucalmo. Tar-Vanimeldë ruled for 111 years. When she died in SA 2637 at the age of 360 years, the Kingship should have gone to her son, Tar-Alcarin, but Herucalmo usurped the throne and ruled for twenty years as King Tar-Anducal. His rule was not considered legitimate, and in the official records Vanimeldë was directly followed by Alcarin.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Alcarin was the son of ruling Queen, Tar-Vanimeldë, and her consort, Herucalmo. When his mother died, Tar-Alcarin should have succeeded her, but Herucalmo usurped the throne and held it from him twenty years before he died, and then Tar-Alcarin rightfully gained the throne. He ruled during a period in which there was still peace in Númenor despite the conflicting beliefs of The Faithful and the King's Men which divided its people. However in Middle-earth things were very different, Sauron's power began to grow once again, spreading great fear through the lands near Mordor. Herucalmo's usurpation of his son's legal right to rule the realm was generally considered to be an evil deed by the people.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Calmacil was also as the first king to have recorded an Adûnaic equivalent of his name: Ar-Belzagar. This signified the continuing alienation of the Kings of Númenor and the party of the King's Men from the traditions of friendship with the Elves.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Gimilzagar was the younger son of King Tar-Calmacil, the eighteenth ruler of the island kingdom. His line of descent made him the great-uncle of Tar-Calmacil's grandson Ar-Adûnakhôr, who broke with tradition by taking his royal name in the Adûnaic tongue. He may have been an ancestor of Inzilbeth, mother of Tar-Palantir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Tar-Ardamin (Quenya; [ta'rardamin]) or Ar-Abattârik is sometimes listed in the list of rulers of Númenor but is sometimes omitted. He was the son of King Tar-Calmacil, and if he is counted as one of the rulers, then he is the nineteenth in the line of kings. Privately, his followers called him by his Adûnaic language name: Ar-Abattârik. Tar-Ardamin was the last to follow the practice of using an official Quenya name. His son Ar-Adûnakhôr then abandoned the old traditions, and began officially using the Adûnaic form of his name.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: As an opponent of the Valar, Ar-Adûnakhôr's Quenya name was recorded in the official royal scrolls only. The name he chose was considered by some as blasphemous in both languages, as it means 'Lord of the West', a title reserved for Manwë, King of the Valar. During his time, the Elven-tongues were no longer used or taught to children, and the ships from Tol Eressëa came rarely. Only those of The Faithful maintained the ancient customs of friendship with the west and welcomed the Eldar, both in secret.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Like his father Ar-Adûnakhôr, Ar-Zimrathôn opposed the Valar, and he took his name in the Adûnaic tongue rather than in the traditional Quenya. But Númenórean scholars recorded his Quenya name Tar-Hostamir in the Scroll of Kings so as not to break with tradition. His name in both languages means 'Jewel Gatherer', perhaps implying a greedy nature. Ar-Zimrathôn died in SA 3033, living to the age of two-hundred and thirty-five and ruled Númenor for seventy-one years, and was succeeded by his son, Ar-Sakalthôr.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: In his time as lord during King Ar-Sakalthôr's reign, the power and influence of the King's Men continued to grow and spread with the Faithful becoming more and more suspect. He successfully led the Faithful through these times. His son (whose name is unknown) became the sixteenth Lord of Andúnië, and had a son Númendil who became the seventeenth Lord of Andúnië. Eärendur's sister Lindórië, a fellow member of the Faithful, was the grandmother of Tar-Palantir. He, like the rest of the Lords of Andúnië, was also the ancestor of the Kings of Gondor and Arnor who would rule in exile in Middle-earth hundreds of years later.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#add500] via-[#b7e100] to-[#add500]

lotr_info.info: Lindórië was the sister of Eärendur, the fifteenth Lord of Andúnië and the mother of Inzilbêth who would later become the Queen to Ar-Gimilzôr, and the grandmother of the future King of Númenor Tar-Palantir. As one of the Faithful, she passed on her beliefs to her daughter and when Inzilbêth and Ar-Gimilzôr had a son she made sure he was raised in the ways of the Faithful.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Ar-Sakalthôr followed the royal tradition of turning away from the ways of the Valar. He succeeded his father Ar-Zimrathôn as King, ruling Númenor for sixty-nine years, and was succeeded by his son, Ar-Gimilzôr. The traditional Quenya version of his name was Tar-Falassion. Ar-Sakalthôr died in SA 3102, living to the age of two-hundred and twenty-six. He ruled Númenor for sixty-nine years and was succeeded by his son, Ar-Gimilzôr.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Inzilbêth was the daughter of Lindórië, who was herself a descendant of Tar-Elendil, the fourth King of Númenor, and also of Tar-Calmacil. Inzilbêth was secretly one of the Faithful, and she passed on her ways to their son, Tar-Palantir. Their second son, Gimilkhâd, opposed his elder brother's policies and continued practising the beliefs of the King's Men in secret.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Ar-Gimilzôr's reign was a difficult time for the Faithful (Elendili), who called for the return of the Númenóreans to the ways of the Valar and the Elves, for during this time he persecuted them for their beliefs. Use of the Elvish languages was forbidden in Númenor by his order in SA 3110. He also neglected the White Tree and no longer made pilgrimage to the Hallow of Eru. In fact, he was so distrustful of the Faithful that he forced them to move from Andúnië to the eastern part of the island near Rómenna, and watched them carefully.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: He came to the throne after his father (whose name is unknown) and became the seventeenth Lord of Andúnië. By the time when Tar-Palantir was King of Númenor, both Lord and King desired a return to the old traditions of Númenor, and they were close friends and political allies. Tar-Palantir would at times travel to see Númendil in Andúnië, and as a Councillor of the Sceptre, Númendil would often journey to the King's seat at Armenelos. Númendil's son Amandil inherited the Lordship of Andúnië, and through him, Númendil would become the ancestor of all Kings of the Dúnedain in Middle-earth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#add500] via-[#b7e100] to-[#add500]

lotr_info.info: Gimilkhâd was considered to be a harsh man. He followed the ways of his father and opposed his brother Inziladûn who changed his name to Tar-Palantir when he became king, intending to repent the ways of his father and follow the ways of the Faithful. Therefore, Gimilkhâd became the leader of the King's Men in Númenór and preserved their ways in secret during the reign of Tar-Palantir. His son, obedient to his father's ways, usurped Tar-Palantir's daughter Míriel who by right deserved to rule as Ruling Queen, and ruled Númenór as king.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Though Tar-Palantir's father, Ar-Gimilzôr, was an opponent of the Valar and the Elves, his mother Inzilbêth taught Tar-Palantir to be an admirer of the Elves. Even by his enemies he was recognized to be a true seer, prophesying that the fate of the White Tree, Nimloth, was tied to that of the House of Elros.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Amandil was the leader of the Faithful in Númenor and became the eighteenth and last Lord of Andúnië. His role as Lord of Andúnië and his dedication as one of the Faithful paved the way for the High Kings of Gondor and Arnor, ensuring their traditions were upheld by the Dúnedain of Middle-earth, culminating in Aragorn II Elessar. Elendil the Tall was his son, and Isildur his grandson.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#add500] via-[#b7e100] to-[#add500]

lotr_info.info: Ar-Pharazôn, or Tar-Calion, later titled 'the Golden', was the twenty-fifth and last King of Númenor. Of all the rulers of Númenor, he wielded the most power, but used it most unwisely; his desire for eternal life which Sauron intentionally and deceptively exploited, caused the Downfall of Númenor and the Change of the World.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#10ff49] via-[#39daff] to-[#10ff49]

lotr_info.info: Zimraphel was born in SA 3117 to Inziladûn (or Tar-Palantir) and was called Míriel in Elvish. Upon a time, she may have been sought after by Elentir, Amandil's brother and Elendil's uncle,[3] but was herself enamored by Pharazôn, her cousin, who was wealthy and highly esteemed. A relationship could have easily arisen between them, as Pharazôn was often abroad, in Númenor's exploits on Middle-earth's coasts.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#b7e100]

lotr_info.info: Elendil (Quenya: 'Elf-friend' or 'Star-lover'), also known as Elendil the Tall/the Fair or Voronda ('The Faithful'), was a man of Númenor and the father of Isildur and Anárion who led the survivors of its Downfall to the shores of Middle-earth where they founded two Realms in Exile: Arnor and Gondor. Thus, Elendil became the first King of both realms and held the title of first High King of the Dúnedain, making him supreme overlord of all exiled Númenóreans in the lands east of the Great Sea. Elendil was killed alongside his friend, the High King Gil-galad, by the Dark Lord Sauron at the Siege of Barad-dûr, in the War of the Last Alliance in the late Second Age.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#46f6ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Isildur and Anárion founded and jointly ruled Gondor in the south, while their father dwelt in Arnor in the north. In the War of the Last Alliance at the end of the Second Age, Isildur cut the One Ring from Sauron's hand, but refused to destroy it. Early in the Third Age, Isildur was betrayed by the Ring which slipped off his finger during the Disaster of the Gladden Fields, leading to the Orcs killing him and Ring being lost for nearly 2,500 years. His refusal to destroy the Ring allowed Sauron to endure and remain a threat to Middle-earth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#46f6ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Anárion was the youngest son of Elendil, the High King of Arnor and Gondor. He and his brother Isildur jointly ruled Gondor, while their father dwelt in the North. Following his father's death during the Siege of Barad-dûr, and Isildur's death at the Disaster of the Gladden Fields, the kingship of Gondor was committed to the line of Anárion beginning with his son, Meneldil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Valandil was the youngest of Isildur's four sons, he was only a child at the time of the War of the Last Alliance, in which his grandfather, Elendil, was killed. Due to this, he remained in Rivendell when his father and brothers went into the south, and was thus the only one of Isildur's sons to survive the Disaster of the Gladden Fields. He received the Shards of Narsil as an heirloom of the Heirs of Isildur when he came of age. Because the Elendilmir had been lost with his father, the Elven smiths of Rivendell created a copy for Valandil, which came to be known itself as the Elendilmir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: He was the only son of Isildur to serve in the army of the Last Alliance, fighting in the Battle of Dagorlad and accompanying his father into Mordor during the Siege of Barad-dûr. His younger brothers were sent to man Minas Ithil, so Sauron could not escape westward by that route. As the eldest son of Isildur, Elendur was high in the confidence of his father; he alone of the sons knew the existence of the One Ring in his father's possession and counselled Isildur to turn over the One Ring to the Keepers of the Three Rings.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Aratan did not take part in the invasion of Mordor or the Siege of Barad-dûr. Instead, his father sent he and his brother Ciryon to Minas Ithil with a force in case Sauron should break or escape the siege through Cirith Dúath, and assail the Dúnedain before he was yet defeated.[3] He like his brothers Elendur and Ciryon, were slain at the Gladden Fields.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Ciryon was the third son of Isildur and Lirulinë Ilmalómë. He was killed while fighting Orcs alongside his father and brothers during the Battle of Gladden Fields in T.A. 2, the second year of the Third Age.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Eldacar was born in TA 87, son of the High King of Arnor Valandil, and through his father, he was the grandson of Isildur. He himself ascended to the throne of Arnor in TA 249 with the death of his father. His reign was without any significant event and Eldacar died in TA 339 at an age of 252, after reigning for ninety years. He was succeeded by his son Arantar.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Arantar ascended the throne of Arnor in TA 339 on the death of his father Eldacar; he was the great-grandson of Isildur. The ninety-six years of his reign was without any major events, and he died in TA 435 at the age of two-hundred and fifty. He was succeeded by his son Tarcil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Tarcil was the sixth King of Arnor. He followed Arantar to the throne in T.A. 435 and ruled until his death in T.A. 515. In his times Tarcil was seen by many comtemporaries as being a bit of an odd sort, he was distrustful and often overcautious and sought close friedship with the Dwarves of the Ered Luin. His son Tarondor of Arnor succeeded him.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Tarondor was the seventh King of Arnor. He succeeded his father Tarcil of Arnor in T.A. 515 and governed until his death in T.A. 602. Unlike his father Tarondor was not known to be much of a paranoid character, but he sensed a decline in the strength of the Dúnedain and strove for outward safety of his realm. His son Valandur of Arnor followed him to the throne in Annúminas.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Valandur was the eighth King of Arnor. He was born in 462 T.A., became King in T.A. 602, and ruled until his unexpected death in an Orc-raid in T.A. 652. He was the son of Tarondor of Arnor and the father of Elendur I of Arnor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Elendur was the son of Valandur, who succeeded his father as High King of Arnor for one hundred and twenty-five years. He was perhaps named for Isildur's eldest son, who also bore the name Elendur. He died in TA 777 and his son Eärendur, who would be the last of Arnor's High Kings, succeeded him. Events from his reign are not precisely known, but it was probably a peaceful one.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Eärendur ascended the throne of Arnor in TA 777 after the death of his father Elendur. When he died, the realm of Arnor became divided and there was rivalry amongst Eärendur's three sons all of which claimed the throne. To prevent civil war, the Kingdom of Arnor was split in the three parts Arthedain, Cardolan, and Rhudaur. He died in TA 861 after ruling for eighty-four years. His oldest son Amlaith became the first King of Arthedain.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Amlaith of Fornost was the eldest son of Eärendur of Arnor and hence a direct descendant of Isildur, Amlaith should by right have succeeded his father to become the eleventh High King of Arnor and lord of all the Dúnedain of the North. After Eärendur's death, however, Amlaith fell into dispute with his younger brothers, and the descent of the kingship was interrupted. The details of the brothers' disagreements are nowhere recorded, but their result was of historical significance, causing the old North-kingdom of the Dúnedain to be split into three realms.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Beleg was the son and heir of King Amlaith of Arthedain, and became king after his father's death in TA 946. During his reign, Hobbits were first seen west of the Misty Mountains, entering Eriador, largely composed of Harfoots. Also during his reign Sauron returned to the western lands, taking up residence at Dol Guldur as the 'Necromancer'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Mallor was the son and heir of King Beleg of Arthedain and became king in TA 1029 at the death of his father, when he was 134 years old. During his reign, the Order of Wizards came to Middle-earth from Valinor, but at the time their origins was not known. Near the end of Mallor's reign it was revealed that the shadow that had fallen over Mirkwood came from Dol Guldur, but Sauron's presence there remained unknown. Mallor died in TA 1110 after ruling for eighty-one years and was succeeded by his son Celepharn.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Celepharn was the son and heir of King Mallor of Arthedain. He came to the throne in TA 1110 at the death of his father. During his reign, many Hobbits entered Eriador. Most of these were Fallohides and Stoors, joining the Harfoots, who had come earlier during the time of Celepharn's grandfather Beleg. During Celepharn's rule, the Southern Kingdom, Gondor reached the height of its power under Atanatar II Alcarin. Celepharn died in TA 1191 after ruling for eighty-one years and was succeeded by his son Celebrindor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Celebrindor was the son of King Celepharn of Arthedain. He came to the throne in TA 1191 at the death of his father. During Celebrindor's rule over Arthedain, there was intermittent skirmishing with Cardolan and Rhudaur, but no major events of note. Celebrindor died in TA 1272 after ruling for eighty-one years and was succeeded by his son Malvegil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Malvegil was the son of King Celebrindor of Arthedain and came to the throne in TA 1272 at the death of his father. Under his rule the enemy realm of Angmar was established by the Witch-king north of the Ettenmoors in the Mountains of Angmar, and evil things began to appear in Eriador. Many Orcs and evil Men began to gather on both sides of the Misty Mountains, and Arthedain was in an uneasy watch ever after. Malvegil died in TA 1349 at the age of two-hundred and five after ruling for seventy-seven years and was succeeded by his son Argeleb I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Because the line of Isildur had failed in the other Dúnedain realms of Cardolan and Rhudaur, Argeleb claimed the Kingship of all of Arnor again, and took the royal prefix ar(a)- as a sign. Cardolan accepted his claim, but it was too late for Rhudaur as it had by then fallen under the control of Angmar and therefore resisted his rule. As a result of this breach, war broke out between the two opposing sides. Argeleb fortified the Weather Hills and was killed defending Weathertop in TA 1356 by evil men from Rhudaur, under the command of the Witch-king of Angmar.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: The beginning and the end of the Arveleg's reign were forged in battle and in war. He came to the throne in TA 1356 when his father Argeleb I went to war against the newly allied lands of Rhudaur and Angmar, and was slain. Arveleg swiftly struck back in alliance with the Men of Cardolan and drove back the invading hordes for a time. For more than fifty years, Arveleg maintained a constant guard stretching from the Weather Hills, along the Great East Road, to the lower reaches of the river Hoarwell. Due in large to the defensive prowess of the Men of Arthedain and Cardolan, Angmar was temporarily pushed back and besieged Rivendell.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Araphor was the son of Arveleg I and came early to the throne of Arthedain. While he was still in his youth (probably no more than eighteen years old), the Witch-king of Angmar launched a mighty invasion of his kingdom, that came close to destroying it. Araphor's father Arveleg fought in the defence of the Tower of Amon Sûl, and his early death in that battle brought Araphor to the throne
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Argeleb was the son of King Araphor of Arthedain, and was named for his great-grandfather Argeleb I. He came to the throne in TA 1589 at the death of his father. During his rule the Great Plague reached Eriador, and most of the people of Cardolan perished, especially in Minhiriath.[3] The Hobbits and other peoples living in Eriador all suffered greatly; but the plague lessened as it went north, and Arthedain was scarcely affected. Evil spirits sent by Angmar passed through Rhudaur to Cardolan, and began to dwell in the Barrow-downs.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Arvegil was born in TA 1553. During his father's reign, Arvegil saw events that would shape the history of Middle-earth, including the foundation of the Shire. He was eighty-three years old (no great age for one of the Dúnedain) when the Great Plague came out of the south and ravaged Eriador, but the seat of the Kings at Fornost in the north was little affected.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Arveleg ascended the throne in TA 1743 at the death of his father, Arvegil. Little of note occurred during his reign, although moderate war continued with Angmar. Arveleg was succeeded at his death in TA 1813 by his son Araval after ruling for seventy-years.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Little is said of his career, but it was hinted that he was a diplomat and a warrior. In alliance with the Elves of Lindon and Rivendell, he won at least one important victory over the Witch-king of Angmar. We are also told that he attempted the recolonization of Cardolan, though this was prevented by the evil beings, the wights, sent there by the Witch-king some two centuries before.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Araphant, the son and heir of King Araval, ascended to the throne in TA 1891 following his father's death. During his reign, the well-known seer Malbeth made a prediction regarding the fate of his son Arvedui, stating that he would be the last king of Arthedain; and as such, he advised Araphant to name his son Arvedui, meaning 'last king'. Malbeth's prophecy included a choice for the Dúnedain: if they took the less hopeful path, Arvedui would not change his name and would remain the last king, leading to much sorrow and many lives lost until the Dúnedain were united again.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Arvedui was the son of King Araphant, and came to the throne in TA 1964 at the death of his father. Arvedui married Fíriel, daughter of King Ondoher of Gondor, who was killed in TA 1944. At Ondoher's death, Arvedui sent messages to Gondor claiming the throne as a direct descendant of Isildur, but he was refused: the Men of Gondor appointed the general Eärnil (a descendant of Anárion) as King instead. Arvedui became King of Arthedain twenty years after, and in TA 1974 Angmar attacked again and captured Fornost. Gondor sent help in the form of a great fleet, but it came too late: Arthedain was destroyed, and Arvedui fled north to the Blue Mountains.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#05bffc] via-[#b7e100] to-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Meneldil was born in Númenor a year before its fall. The only son and fourth child of Anárion, he was said to be the last child born in Númenor before its downfall. He had three older siblings, all sisters. After the War of the Last Alliance in which his father Anárion was slain, Meneldil was groomed by his uncle Isildur for a few years to rule Gondor, since Isildur and his sons intended to go north to rule Arnor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Cemendur succeeded his father Meneldil to the throne of Gondor in TA 158. Very little is known of his reign, only that it was a peaceful one like most all of the very early Kings of Gondor. He died in TA 238 at the age of two hundred eighty, after a rule of eighty years and was succeeded by his son Eärendil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Eärendil was the son of Cemendur. During his reign there were no significant events, which suggests a peaceful reign. He died in TA 324 after ruling Gondor for 86 years and living for 276 years, he was succeeded by his son Anardil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Anardil was born in TA 136.[1] He ascended to the throne after the death of his father Eärendil in TA 324. No notable events were recorded for his reign, suggesting it was a peaceful one. Anardil died in TA 411 aged 275 after a rule of eighty-seven years and was succeeded by his son Ostoher.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: He moved his summer residence from the capital city of Osgiliath to the fortress of Minas Anor in TA 420. During this time he rebuilt and greatly added to it and over time it would become a city as well as a fortress, until after the Great Plague of 1636 when it became the capital of Gondor, over twelve-hundred years later. In the last two years of his reign the Easterlings started attacks on Gondor. Due to his advanced age, he sent his son Tarostar (later Rómendacil) to meet the Easterling threat, who was victorious.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Rómendacil, initially named Tarostar, was the son of King Ostoher. When the Easterlings invaded in TA 490, Tarostar as crown-prince was charged with leading the defense against them, as Ostoher was too old. He succeeded his father upon his death in TA 492. Tarostar defeated the Easterlings, after many battles, by TA 500. After the victory he renamed himself Rómendacil, meaning 'East-victor'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Turambar was the son and successor of Rómendacil I. He ascended to the throne in TA 541 at a relatively young age. He avenged the death of his father and proceeded to conquer large parts of Rhûn from the Easterlings expanding Gondor further into the east. The conquered lands became the eastern territories of Gondor. He was the longest reigning king since Meneldil, ruling for 126 years. He was succeeded by his son Atanatar I upon his death in TA 667 at the age of two-hundred and seventy.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Atanatar was the son of Turambar and succeeded his father to the throne of Gondor in TA 667. His reign was uneventful and presumably peaceful. He died in TA 748 and was succeeded by his son Siriondil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Siriondil became King of Gondor in TA 748 after the death of his father Atanatar I. He had two sons, Tarannon and Tarciryan. His reign was without notable events and probably peaceful. He ruled for eighty-two years and died in TA 830 at the age of two-hundred and sixty years of age and was succeeded by his son, Tarannon.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Tarannon succeeded his father Siriondil in TA 830. His brother was Tarciryan. He started the construction of Gondor's navies, and became known as the first of the Ship-kings. Under his policies and successful rule, Gondor's extended its power to the west and south of the Mouths of Anduin. He, along with Narmacil I, was one of two childless Kings of Gondor, making him a break-point in the bloodline. Nevertheless his rule was marked by such vigorous naval expansion that at his coronation he assumed the additional regnal name of Falastur, meaning 'Lord of the Coasts'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Berúthiel was a Black Númenórean, from an inland city located somewhere within Harad, possibly to the south of Umbar. Tarannon's reason for marrying Berúthiel is untold. Berúthiel loathed the sounds and the smells of the sea, fish, and the gulls. She also hated the house that Tarannon had built below Pelargir on arches that stood in the water of the Ethir Anduin. As a result, she lived in the King's House in Osgiliath instead. Berúthiel hated all colors and elaborate adornments, wearing only plain black and silver garments. Though she lived in bare chambers in the King's Housise, she decorated its gardens with tormented sculptures beneath cypresses and yews.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Tarciryan was the son of Siriondil and the younger brother of Tarannon Falastur. Tarciryan was the father of the future King Eärnil I of Gondor. He predeceased his elder brother Tarannon and thus the throne passed directly to his son.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Eärnil was born in TA 736 to Tarciryan, the brother of King Tarannon Falastur. Tarannon Falastur died without a natural heir and Eärnil, his nephew succeeded him in TA 913. His policies where to continue to expand the realm of Gondor. He repaired the ancient port of Pelargir and built up a great naval fleet. He later laid siege to the enemy city of Umbar in TA 933 and captured it. He was tragically lost at sea near Umbar in TA 936, and was succeeded by his son Ciryandil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Ciryandil was born in the year TA 820 and succeeded his father Eärnil I in TA 936. In his reign, Ciryandil continued Eärnil's naval policies and spent his reign defending the recently captured port of Umbar against the Black Númenóreans who had lived there before, and the Haradrim who wished to capture the port. In TA 1015 after a reign of 79 years, he was slain in the siege of Umbar. He was succeeded by his son Ciryaher (later named Hyarmendacil).
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Hyarmendacil was born Ciryaher to King Ciryandil, who was slain defending Umbar, under siege by the Haradrim and Black Númenóreans. As Gondor's enemies to the south had yet to be subdued or pacified, he began his reign by reorganizing Gondor's armies. He launched a great assault by land and sea on the Haradrim in TA 1050 and won a great victory, lifting the siege of Umbar and breaking the power of the Black Númenóreans for good. The Haradrim were forced to recognize him as their overlord and paid tribute to Gondor, and their sons where forced to live as hostages in the court of the king. After this victory, he called himself Hyarmendacil, meaning South-victor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Atanatar was born in the year TA 977. Atanatar succeeded his father Hyarmendacil I in TA 1149 as the sixteenth King of Gondor. His wealth was so great that historians remarked that 'precious stones are pebbles in Gondor for children to play with'. He was also known as Atanatar Alcarin, 'Atanatar the Glorious', (alcarin being the Quenya word for glorious), but the deeds of Atanatar weren't as glorious as his appellation would indicate. Atanatar made no effort to expand or maintain the power that his father commanded and the guard on Mordor was neglected. Therefore, his reign is seen as the start of Gondor's decline.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Narmacil was born in the year TA 1049 to Atanatar II and his unnamed wife. He was as lazy as his father and was soon tired of being king. Intending to pursue his own personal pleasures and activities, he created the office of Regent and surrendered practical rule to his nephew Minalcar by TA 1240 (who would eventually become king in his own right). During his reign, the Easterlings started to become a threat again and his regent's main concern was making alliance with the tribes of the Northmen to help fight against them. Narmacil died childless in TA 1294 after reigning sixty four years and ruling for fourteen, he was succeeded by his brother Calmacil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Calmacil was the eighteenth King of Gondor and the brother of Narmacil I, whom he succeeded as King in TA 1294. His elder son was Minalcar (aka Rómendacil II) and his younger son was Calimehtar. His reign lasted for ten years, during which his son Minalcar continued to rule as Regent, an office he had held during Narmacil's reign. In TA 1304 Calmacil died and was succeeded by Minalcar.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Calimehtar was the younger son of Calmacil, the 18th King of Gondor. His child's name is not known, but his grandson Castamir became the 22nd King of Gondor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: RómendacilII was 'Regent of the realm' of Gondor from TA 1240 and struck a decisive blow against the Easterlings, whom he heavily defeated in TA 1248 near the Sea of Rhûn. He also fortified Gondor and made pacts with the Northmen of Rhovanion, all before he took the throne. After Narmacil's death, he remained Regent for ten years under his father Calmacil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Valacar was born in the year 1194 during the Third Age. Valacar's father, Minalcar, the regent of Gondor, sent Valacar as an ambassador to Vidugavia, a prince of the Northmen who called himself 'King of Rhovanion'. Minalcar charged Valacar to learn the language, manners and policies of the Northmen. During his stay in Rhovanion, Valacar learned to love the country and the Northmen. With the approval of his father, Valacar married Vidumavi, the daughter of Vidugavia in that time.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Valacar was born in the year 1194 during the Third Age. Valacar's father, Minalcar, the regent of Gondor, sent Valacar as an ambassador to Vidugavia, a prince of the Northmen who called himself 'King of Rhovanion'. Minalcar charged Valacar to learn the language, manners and policies of the Northmen. During his stay in Rhovanion, Valacar learned to love the country and the Northmen. With the approval of his father, Valacar married Vidumavi, the daughter of Vidugavia in that time.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: His parents' names aren't known, but his grandfather was Calimehtar, the younger son of Gondor's King Calmacil. Castamir was not in line for the throne, but his royal background had made him the Lord of Ships under the previous king, Valacar. His lineage and influence left him in a position to challenge the new king, Eldacar, who was only half Dúnadan, and half Northmen. As King Valacar's only son, Eldacar was the legitimate heir to the throne, but his half Northmen lineage angered those who believed in a pure Dúnedain royalty. Capitalizing on these feelings, Castamir was able to incite rebellion and besiege Eldacar within the capital Osgiliath in TA 1437 of the Third Age.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Aldamir was the second son of King Eldacar of Gondor and succeeded him in TA 1490, because his elder brother Ornendil was executed by Castamir during the Kin-strife. Aldamir's years as king were marked by constant warfare with the Corsairs of Umbar (led by the sons of Castamir) and the Haradrim. He was slain in battle with the Men of Harad and Corsairs of Umbar in TA 1540 and was succeeded by his son Vinyarion.
