lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Ornendil was the elder son of King Eldacar of Gondor. In the Siege of Osgiliath during the Kin-strife, Omendil's father was driven out by Castamir the Usurper. Unfortunately, Ornendil did not escape with his father and was put to death by Castamir upon the fall of Osgiliath in TA 1437.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Hyarmendacil was the son of King Aldamir and reigned from TA 1540 until TA 1621. Born as Vinyarion, his father Aldamir was slain in a war with the Haradrim in TA 1540 and Vinyarion wished to avenge his death. He accomplished this in TA 1551 by invading Harad and winning a great victory over the Haradrim, proclaiming himself Hyarmendacil II, meaning in Quenya 'South-victor' after his famous ancestor from the twelfth century of the Third Age. He died in TA 1621 after a rule of eighty-one years, at age two hundred thirty and was succeeded by his son Minardil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Angamaitë was the great-grandson of Castamir. Along with Sangahyando, he became an important figure amongst the Haradrim and the Corsairs of Umbar. Angamaitë was a descendant of the rebel Castamir and carried on the traditional hatred against Gondor. In TA 1634, King Minardil was at Pelargir without fear of any attack. Angamaitë and Sangahyando soon learned about this through spies and sacked the city, killing Minardil and seizing great amounts of treasure.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Sangahyando, like Angamaitë, was probably born in Umbar to an unnamed mother and father. As descendants of the rebel Castamir, they carried on the traditional hatred against Gondor. In TA 1634, when King Minardil was at Pelargir, spies of Sangahyando and Angamaitë told them about the king's visit to the city. They launched a surprise attack, killing the king and sacking the city. His ultimate fate is unknown.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Minardil was born in TA 1454 during the reign of his great-grandfather Eldacar and was the son and successor of King Hyarmendacil II whom he succeeded in TA 1621. His reign was brief and turbulent. His steward, Húrin of Emyn Arnen, would found the line of the House of Húrin, who became Ruling Stewards centuries later. In TA 1634, he was at Pelargir when it was suddenly attacked by the Corsairs of Umbar and he was slain. Minardil ruled for thirteen years. He had two sons: his eldest son Telemnar (who succeeded him) and his younger son Minastan.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Telemnar became King after his father, Minardil, died in an attack by the Corsairs of Umbar at Pelargir in TA 1634. Due to this renewed threat from the Corsairs, he immediately began building up Gondor's fleets to defeat them; but was forced to stop when the Great Plague struck. This plague ravaged Gondor and many died; especially in Osgiliath and Minas Ithil. During the plague, both Telemnar and his children died. The White Tree also withered and died during this time. He was succeeded by his nephew Tarondor, the son of Telemnar's younger brother Minastan. His father's reign was brief but his own reign was even briefer. He was the shortest reigning King of Gondor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: He was born sometime after TA 1516, the second son of Minardil and father of Tarondor. His elder brother Telemnar was King of Gondor for only two years until he died in the Great Plague of TA 1636. It is not known when Minastan died, possibly in the Plague, but he predeceased his older brother. Minastan's son succeeded Telemnar on the throne, beginning a new line.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: The Plague had devastated Gondor, and Tarondor strove to slowly rebuild it and its power. He pursued a policy of strict retrenchment, in which many outposts were abandoned. The most significant event in his reign was the removal of the capital from the now depopulated Osgiliath, to Minas Anor (later known as Minas Tirith) and the replanting of the White Tree.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Telumehtar succeeded his father Tarondor as King in TA 1798. Early in his reign, the Corsairs of Umbar raided the coasts of Gondor and terrorized shipping in the Bay of Belfalas. King Telemnar had been preparing an expedition to avenge the death of his father Minardil, but the outbreak of the Great Plague sapped Gondor's strength. 174 years later, Telumehtar resolved to end the war and gain vengeance, so he assembled a large force in TA 1810 and recaptured the city of Umbar. After this event he took the title Umbardacil, meaning 'Victor over Umbar'. In this war, the Corsairs suffered total defeat and the descendants of Castamir the Usurper all perished. Umbar was for a time held again by Gondor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Narmacil II was the twenty-ninth King of Gondor and the son of Telumehtar. In the second year of his reign a confederation of Easterlings called the Wainriders began to raid the eastern territories of Gondor. Five years later they invaded in force, overrunning the eastern territories. Narmacil marched to Rhovanion to fight the invaders but was utterly defeated and slain in the Battle of the Plains. He was one-hundred and seventy-two years old and ruled for only six years. He was succeeded by his son Calimehtar.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Arciryas was the son of King Telumehtar Umbardacil and the younger brother of King Narmacil II. Nothing is told of his life except that he married an unnamed woman and had a son, Calimmacil, who would be the grandfather of Eärnil II.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Calimehtar was a good friend and ally of the Northmen, whose leader Marhwini warned him in TA 1899 that the Wainriders were planning a new invasion of Gondor. To pre-empt this, Calimehtar assembled an army in Ithilien which he marched north, also sending cavalry over the Undeeps to harass the unguarded enemy positions there. Calimehtar and his Northmen allies finally met the Wainriders on Dagorlad where they defeated them. Narmacil II's death had been avenged. The victory of Gondor and its allies inspired the slaves in Rhovanion to revolt against their cruel Easterling masters.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Calimmacil was a nobleman of Gondor during the mid-Third Age. Calimmacil was the son of Arciryas, and thus the nephew of Narmacil II. At some point prior to TA 1883, he became the father of Siriondil, who would become the father of Eärnil II.[1] Nothing further is known of his life.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Ondoher succeeded his father Calimehtar in TA 1936. During his time the rulers of Gondor and Arthedain became aware that a power was coordinating attacks on the Exiles of Númenor, leading to the two kingdoms to renew contact and form an alliance. Ondoher's daughter Fíriel married Prince Arvedui of Arthedain. In TA 1944, the Wainriders invaded Gondor from the east while their allies, the Haradrim, invaded Gondor from the south. Ondoher and his eldest son and heir, Artamir, led the main army close to the Black Gate, where they clashed with the Wainriders. The left wing of Ondoher's army was commanded by Adrahil, the Prince of Dol Amroth. The right wing was commanded by Minohtar, the captain of Gondor's armies. The center was commanded by Ondoher himself.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Siriondil was the son of Calimmacil and grandson of Arciryas, brother of Narmacil II. He may have been named after his ancestor Siriondil, the eleventh King of Gondor. Siriondil had at least one son, Eärnil, who was born in TA 1883. As Eärnil was named King a year after the death of Ondoher in TA 1944, Siriondil likely died prior to this date.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Fíriel was the only daughter of King Ondoher of Gondor. She had two elder brothers, Artamir and Faramir. Fíriel was wedded to Prince Arvedui of Arthedain in TA 1940 during a time when Arvedui's father Araphant made an alliance with Ondoher. They had one son named Aranarth. The alliance came to nothing and was a failure because both of the Dúnedain Kingdoms were under attack: Arnor by Angmar under the Witch-king, and Gondor by the Wainriders from the east.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: In TA 1944, Faramir was not willing to remain in Minas Anor as Regent while his father and brother went to war with the returning Wainriders, despite this being the law. Leaving Minas Anor in disguise, he joined a party of Éothéod retreating towards the Dead Marshes near the Morannon. The group was caught in an ambush of some kind, and he was mortally wounded, dying in the arms of the leader of his party, who then defended his body until help arrived. His true identity was discovered when the Éothéod searched his body and found evidence that he was a Prince of Gondor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: During his father's reign a great tragedy stuck: the invasion of Wainriders from the east in TA 1944, who had formed an alliance with the Haradrim of the south. Thus, Gondor was attacked from two fronts. Artamir and Ondoher led an army to Ithilien, preparing for the assault from the north. However, the Wainriders unexpectedly descended on them from the east instead. This resulted in an utter defeat for Gondor, and Artamir, his father and brother all perished
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: In the previous year a two-pronged attack had been launched upon Gondor by the Haradrim and the Wainriders. In response, King Ondoher led the main army north to counter the Easterling invasion, but was ambushed before the Black Gate, defeated and killed. Eärnil was commander of Gondor's southern army and guarded Ithilien. Eärnil led his army into Southern Ithilien where he won a great victory over the Haradrim and Variags. This enabled him to turn his attention to the invading Wainriders. The Wainriders, certain of victory, were celebrating their success before entering Minas Anor. They were unaware of Eärnil's victory in the south and were taken by surprise when Eärnil, having linked up with elements of the retreating Northern Army, suddenly attacked them. As a result Eärnil overwhelmed and destroyed them in the Battle of the Camp.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Minohtar was a descendant of Anárion and sister-son of Ondoher, King of Gondor. In TA 1944 when the army of King Ondoher went out to fight the Wainriders, Minohtar was appointed Captain of the Right Wing of Gondor's armies in the battle. The Right Wing was to follow the king and his body guards to the Black Gate and onto the Dagorlad. However, the Wainriders sent their cavalry to launch a surprise attack on the main force, which the king was leading. The Wainrider assault overwhelmed the centre of the army, and King Ondoher fell. Minohtar then rallied his wing of the army to mount a desperate rear-guard defense, buying time for the un-engaged left wing of the army and the units at the rear of the ring wing to retreat. Minohtar and his men conducted a fighting retreat, but were ultimately overwhelmed at the entrance to Ithilien. Minohtar was one of the casualties of the battle, slain by an enemy arrow.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fbb9ff]

lotr_info.info: Eärnur was the thirty-third and last King of Gondor until the accession of Aragorn II Elessar. He took the throne upon the death of his father Eärnil II in TA 2043, and after his disappearance the Stewards of Gondor ruled in his name for many generations.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#fbb9ff] to-[#7c35ab]

lotr_info.info: Aranarth was the first Chieftain of the Dúnedain, and would have been King of Arnor at the death of his father Arvedui, last King of Arthedain, had the North Kingdom not fallen. He was chieftain for longer than anyone after him, ruling for 131 years.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Arahael was the first of Isildur's Heirs to be born after the destruction of the North-kingdom. His father Aranarth therefore gave him over to Elrond while he dwelt in the wild, to be fostered in Rivendell, and this became the custom of the Chieftains of the North.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Aranuir was the son of Arahael and great-grandson of Arvedui Last-King. He was the direct ancestor of Aragorn II Elessar through thirteen generations. Aranuir died in TA 2247.[2] Little is recorded of Aranuir's life or reign but it could be assumed that it was relatively uneventful, coinciding with the Watchful Peace.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Aravir was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Aranuir dwelt in the wild. At his father's death in TA 2247, Aravir in turn became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain. Little of his reign is recorded, but was likely peaceful, as it coincided with the Watchful Peace. Aravir died in TA 2319 after serving as Chieftain seventy-two years, and was followed by his son Aragorn I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Aragorn I was born to Aravir in TA 2227 during the time of the Watchful Peace. After his father's death in TA 2319, Aragorn I succeeded him as the Chieftain of the Dúnedain. Aragorn I's reign came to an early end when, in TA 2327, he became 'lost in the wilderness' while hunting.[2] It was later said in history that he was probably slain by the Wolves infesting Eastern Eriador,[2] which remained an ever increasing danger in Eriador, even up to the Fourth Age.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, Araglas was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Aragorn I dwelt in the wild. Aragorn was killed by a pack of wild wolves in TA 2327, and Araglas succeed him as Chieftain of the Dúnedain while still very young by the reckoning of his people. He died in TA 2455 after 128 years as chieftain and was succeeded by his son Arahad I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, Arahad was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Araglas dwelt in the wild. He became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in TA 2455 at the death of his father. During his rule as chieftain, it was discovered that the Necromancer had returned to Dol Guldur, and the Watchful Peace came to an end in TA 2460. Some time later the Misty Mountains were once again invaded by the Orcs. In TA 2509 Elrond's wife Celebrían was taken by Orcs and tortured. She later left Middle-earth for Valinor. Arahad died in TA 2523 after serving as chieftain for sixty-eight years, and was followed by his son Aragost.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, Aragost was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Arahad I dwelt in the wild. He became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in TA 2523 at the death of his father. His rule was an uneventful one, as the attention of the enemy was focused on Gondor, where the Éothéod had settled the new realm of Rohan. He died in TA 2588, after serving as chieftain for sixty-five years, and was succeeded by his son Aravorn.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, Aravorn was raised by Elrond Half-elven in Rivendell. Aravorn became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in the year TA 2588 at the death of his father. During Aravorn's rule, the Orc and Wolf attacks continued as the strength of the Dark Lord Sauron slowly began to increase. Aravorn died in the year TA 2654 after serving as chieftain for sixty-six years, and was followed by his son Arahad II.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, Arahad was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Aravorn dwelt in the wild. He became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in TA 2654 at the death of his father. During his rule the Hobbits of the Shire prospered under the protection of the Rangers, and the first pipe-weed was planted in the Shire's Southfarthing. In the Shire, Isengrim II became the Thain and began digging the Great Smials. Arahad died in TA 2719 after serving as chieftain for sixty-five years, and was followed by his son Arassuil.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: During his rule, he fought off Orc raids coming from the Misty Mountains and into Eriador, but was unable to prevent a force from reaching the Shire, where the hobbits defeated the enemy themselves under Bandobras Took. During his rule, a great and perilous Long Winter arrived in TA 2759, which fell upon Eriador and took the lives of many. Gandalf and the Rangers had to help the Hobbits of the Shire live through it. Arassuil died in TA 2784 after serving as chieftain for sixty-five years, and was succeeded by his son, Arathorn I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, he was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Arassuil dwelt in the wild. Arathorn became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in TA 2784 at the death of his father. His rule was largely an uneventful one, as the Dúnedain and other peoples of Eriador were recovering from the Long Winter. At the southern fringes of his realm, great events occurred: the Dwarven King Thrór was slain by Azog, an Orc of Moria. From TA 2793 – TA 2799, the War of the Dwarves and Orcs was fought all through the Misty Mountains, as Dwarves from all Seven Houses gathered to avenge Thrór, the Heir of Durin.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, Argonui was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Arathorn I dwelt in the wild. He became the Chieftain of the Dúnedain in TA 2848, when his father was killed by wolves. During his rule, Gandalf entered Dol Guldur and discovered that it was Sauron who ruled there as he long had feared, and not the Witch-king of Angmar his servant. Thráin II the Dwarf died after giving Gandalf a map and a key. The White Council met in TA 2850, where Gandalf urged an attack on Dol Guldur to drive Sauron out, but Saruman overruled him.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Arador descended in direct line from Aranarth being born in TA 2820. He took the chieftainship in TA 2912 after his father Argonui died. During the time of his reign, the majority of the Dúnedain lived in the Angle of Eriador. Arador himself lived in a house by the Hoarwell in some woods north of the Trollshaws. During his reign, Trolls began to make dens in the mountains and hills of the Ettenmoors. A band of these trolls threatened Arador's house in the Angle.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Dirhael was born in the late Third Age, and grew up at the Black Gate, where he became a ranger like his father, Talion. Due to the frontier nature of their home, he was accustomed to a disciplinary lifestyle. During Sauron's initial attack on the Black Gate, marking the beginning of his reconquest of Mordor, Dirhael fought against Sauron's uruks along with his father and the other rangers stationed at the gates. However, he was captured by the Tower of Sauron along with his family, and was with them afterwards murdered by the Black Hand as part of a dark ritual.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Ivorwen was the daughter of Gilbarad, the wife of Dírhael, the mother of Gilraen, and grandmother of Aragorn. She was considered by many of her people to be foresighted.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Like his forefathers, he was raised by Elrond in Rivendell while his father Arador dwelt in the wild. Arathorn asked for the hand of Gilraen at a very young age. Though her father Dírhael initially opposed the marriage, his wife prevailed upon him to agree to the match, as she foresaw that an early death awaited Arathorn.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#abd33c] via-[#05bffc] to-[#abd33c]

lotr_info.info: Gilraen was the wife of Arathorn II and mother of Aragorn II, the future King Elessar of the Reunited Kingdom. Gilraen was born in TA 2907. Her father was Dírhael and her mother was Ivorwen. Gilraen married Arathorn son of Arador in TA 2929. Her father Dírhael was opposed to the match because he felt Gilraen was too young to marry and because he had a sense of foreboding that Arathorn would not live long. But Ivorwen counseled her husband to acquiesce, saying 'If these two wed now, hope may be born for our people; but if they delay, it will not come while this age lasts'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#05bffc]

lotr_info.info: Aragorn II, son of Arathorn II and Gilraen, also known as Strider and Elessar, was the 16th and last Chieftain of the Dúnedain of the North; later crowned King Elessar Telcontar (March 1, 2931 - FO 120), the 26th King of Arnor, 35th King of Gondor and first High King of Gondor and Arnor since the short reign of Isildur. He was a great ranger and warrior, and bore, as Isildur's heir, the shards of Narsil, reforged and renamed Andúril ('Flame of the West') in the War of the Ring.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#00ff15] to-[#bdff43]

lotr_info.info: Eldarion was born in the first year of the Fourth Age. and became second King of the Reunited Kingdom after the death of his father in FO 120. He was considered a third generation Half-elf, having a slow maturity and long youth like true Elves, while not inheriting the choice of becoming immortal. It was said that he had an appearance of 20 years old until he was 60. At the time of his ascension to the throne, Eldarion was 'full ripe and ready for kingship'. It is known that Eldarion was given the tokens of kingship such as the Crown of Gondor, by his father, who died soon after the crowning of his son. He was also recorded to have several sisters.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#7c35ab] via-[#00ff15] to-[#bdff43]

lotr_info.info: Húrin of Emyn Arnen is the earliest of Gondor's Stewards to be recorded in history. He served under King Minardil, with great distinction. He was a man of noble Númenórean heritage, the originator of the House of Húrin whence came Minardil's heirs, by tradition, to select their own Stewards. He probably died in the Great Plague of 1636.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Pelendur was born in TA 1879, he was a descendant of Húrin of Emyn Arnen, an earlier Steward of Gondor and the grandfather of Mardil Voronwë, the first Ruling Steward of Gondor. Pelendur helped Gondor through a constitutional crisis following the premature death of King Ondoher and his heirs in battle in TA 1944. He effectively ruled the kingdom for one year while observing the claims of the two claimants, Prince Arvedui of Arthedain and the general Eärnil who was victorious in battle against the Wainriders (Easterlings).
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Vorondil, also known as Vorondil the Hunter, was the Steward to the King Eärnil II of Gondor. Born in TA 1919, Vorondil was the son of the Steward Pelendur. Following the death of his father, Pelendur in TA 1998 Vorondil succeeded him and became the Steward to King Eärnil II. Vorondil served as the Steward to King Eärnil II until his death in TA 2029 at the age of 110 years old. Vorondil was succeeded by his son Mardil Voronwë who later became the first of the Ruling Stewards. Vorondil was called the hunter because of his prowess hunting. He hunted the Kine of Araw, and from its horn was fashioned the Horn of Gondor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Mardil Voronwë was the son of the Vorondil, a great hunter of beasts. By his time the position of Steward of Gondor was already hereditary and Mardil received the title of Steward on the death of his father in TA 2029. His Stewardship began during the last part of the reign of King Eärnil II and throughout the reign of Eärnur, Eärnil's son.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Eradan was born in TA 1999 and was the son of Mardil Voronwë. Following the death of his father in TA 2080, Eradan became the second Ruling Steward, and the second Steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. Eradan, served as Ruling Steward until his death in TA 2116 at the age of 117 after a rule of thirty-six years. He was succeeded by his son Herion. Eradan was the first Steward to use a Sindarin name.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Following the death of his father, Eradan, in TA 2116 Herion became the third Ruling Steward, and the third steward to rule during the Watchful Peace. He died in TA 2148 at the age of 111, and was succeeded by his son Belegorn. He was the grandson of Mardil Voronwë.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Belegorn was born in TA 2074[1] and was the son of Herion. Following the death of his father, Herion, in TA 2148 Belegorn became the fourth Ruling Steward of Gondor, and the fourth steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. Belegorn ruled Gondor until his death in the year TA 2204 at the age of 130. He was succeeded by his son Húrin I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Húrin was born in TA 2124, and was the son of Belegorn. He was descended from Húrin of Emyn Arnen, one of the stewards in the days of the Kings of Gondor and founder of the House of Húrin. His name was taken in the likeness of Húrin, hero of the Edain in the Elder Days and father of Túrin Turambar.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2165, Túrin I was the third child and only son of Húrin I and was likely named after the First Age hero, Túrin Turambar. Following the death of his father, Húrin I, in TA 2244 Túrin I became the sixth Ruling Steward of Gondor, and the sixth steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. Twice married, Túrin had several daughters and one son. Túrin's youngest child and his only son Hador was born in TA 2245 when Turin was eighty years old. Túrin I died in the year TA 2278 after thirty-four years of rule at the age of 113 years old and was succeeded by his son Hador.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Hador was born in TA 2245 and was the only son of his father Túrin I. Following his father's death in TA 2278 Hador became the seventh Ruling Steward of Gondor, and the seventh steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. During his time as Steward and on the three hundredth anniversary of the Steward's Reckoning, the calendar system created by Mardil Voronwë was modified by Hador, adding one day to it to make it more accurate. Hador ruled Gondor until his death in TA 2395 at the age of 150 years old after a rule of one-hundred and seventeen years. Upon his death he was succeeded by his son Barahir. Hador was the last noble Man of Gondor to live such a long life.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2290, Barahir was the son of Hador. Following the death of his father, Hador, in TA 2395 Barahir became the eighth Ruling Steward of Gondor, and the eighth steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. The realm during this time was relatively free of any troubles. Barahir ruled Gondor for seventeen years until his death in TA 2412 at the age of 122 years old, and was succeeded by his son Dior.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Dior was born in TA 2328, Dior was the son of Barahir. Following the death of his father, Barahir, in TA 2412 Dior became the ninth Ruling Steward of Gondor, and the ninth Steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. Dior ruled Gondor until his death in TA 2435 at the age of 107 years old after a rule of twenty-three years. Dior had no son and thus no direct heir so at the time of his death, the line of succession passed from Dior to his nephew Denethor I, the son of his sister Rían.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Rían was the daughter of the Steward Barahir. When her brother the Steward Dior died childless and thus without an heir, her son Denethor I became the new Ruling Steward of Gondor. Her fate is unknown. Her name may have been influenced by the Edain woman Rían, the wife of the First Age hero Huor.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#f6e45c]

lotr_info.info: Following the death of his uncle in TA 2435 Denethor I became the tenth Ruling Steward of Gondor. Denethor I was the last Steward to rule during the era known as the Watchful Peace. After ruling Gondor peacefully for twenty five years, the Watchful Peace ended in TA 2460 with the return of Sauron to Dol Guldur. In TA 2475 Sauron's forces attacked Gondor, unleashing the dreaded Black Uruks, a new race of black Orcs heavier and stronger than any seen before. They destroyed Osgiliath and broke its great stone-bridge leaving it ruined and abandoned from then on. However, the Men of Gondor under the leadership of Denethor I's son Boromir recaptured Ithilien from Sauron's forces, and drove them back east of the river. Denethor I died two years later in the year TA 2477 at the age of 102 after a rule of forty-two years. He was succeeded by his son Boromir.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Boromir was born in TA 2410, the third child of Denethor I. Boromir successfully recaptured Ithilien from elements of Sauron's army headquartered at Minas Morgul after their invasion of Gondor in TA 2475. He was considered such a mighty captain and warrior that even the Witch-king feared him, but the retaking of Ithilien by the Men of Gondor under Boromir's command ultimately proved to be a pyrrhic victory for three reasons: First, the land of Ithilien remained largely depopulated due to its close proximity to Minas Morgul and the threat it posed. Second, the invasion left the ancient capital of Gondor, Osgiliath, in ruins. Last, the poisoned wounds received by Boromir shortened his lifespan, leaving him shrunken and in constant pain. Two years later Boromir succeeded his father as the Ruling Steward of Gondor in the year TA 2477.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2449, Cirion was the son of Boromir, the eleventh Ruling Steward of Gondor. Cirion became the twelfth Steward when his father died in TA 2489. During his rule in TA 2509, the Balchoth gathered for an assault upon Gondor. Cirion repaired the forts guarding the Undeeps and prepared as best he could, but could not spare many men to defend this part of his realm, and in despair he sent several messengers to Gondor's old friends the Éothéod, a people now living in the Vales of Anduin to the far north.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Hallas was born in TA 2480 and was the son of Cirion. When Cirion died in TA 2567, Hallas succeeded him as Ruling Steward. Calenardhon had been given by his father to the Éothéod, and Hallas grew particularly friendly with the new arrivals and devised the names Rochand and Rochirrim for the land and its people, which became Rohan and Rohirrim in the Sindarin dialect of Gondor. In effect, Gondor had been halved in size, but it had gained a strong ally to the north in return.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2515, Húrin II was the son of Hallas. Húrin II succeeded his father as Steward in TA 2605. Sporadic warfare on Gondor's eastern and southern borders continued. Other than minor skirmishes no events are recorded during his rule. Húrin II died in TA 2628 after twenty-three years of rule at the age of 113 years old. He was followed by his son Belecthor I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2545, Belecthor I was the son of Húrin II. Belecthor I succeeded his father as Steward in TA 2628. The Corsairs of Umbar were the major threat to Gondor at the time, although no major events are recorded. Other than minor skirmishes no events are recorded during his rule. Belecthor had two children: Morwen, a daughter, and Orodreth. Belecthor I died in TA 2655 at the age of 110 years old after a rule of twenty-seven years. He was followed by his son Orodreth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2576, Orodreth was the son of Belecthor I. Orodreth succeeded his father as Steward in TA 2655. The Corsairs of Umbar were the major threat to Gondor at the time, although no major events are recorded. Orodreth died in TA 2685 at the age of 109 years old. He was followed by his son Ecthelion I.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Morwen was the daughter of the Steward Belecthor I, sister of Orodreth, sixteenth Ruling Steward of Gondor, and was the grandmother of Egalmoth, the eighteenth Ruling Steward of Gondor. Little is known about Morwen other than her lineage and the actions of her family, although she was a direct descendant of the House of Húrin. All of the Stewards after Egalmoth were directly descended from her.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#f6e45c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2600, Ecthelion was the son of Orodreth. Ecthelion succeeded his father as Steward in TA 2685. Although, the Corsairs of Umbar were the major threat to Gondor at the time, the most notable event during his reign was the rebuilding of the White Tower in Minas Tirith. In his honour it later became known as the Tower of Ecthelion. Ecthelion I died childless in TA 2698 at the age of ninety-eight. Since, Ecthelion I had no children at the time of his death, afterwards the Stewardship of Gondor passed to Egalmoth, Ecthelion's first cousin once removed.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Egalmoth was born in TA 2626. He was the grandson of Morwen, the daughter of Belecthor I, and the great-nephew of Orodreth. When the seventeenth Ruling Steward Ecthelion I died in TA 2698 without issue, Egalmoth succeeded his cousin as Steward. The majority of Egalmoth's rule passed uneventfully, likely with minor warfare against the Corsairs of Umbar and forces of Minas Morgul. Egalmoth died in TA 2743 at the age of 117, after a rule of forty-five years, and was succeeded by his son Beren.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Beren was born in TA 2655 and was the son of Egalmoth. When Egalmoth died in TA 2743, Beren succeeded him as the Ruling Steward. He spent much of his reign fighting the Corsairs of Umbar. During the Long Winter of TA 2758 to TA 2759, the Corsairs of Umbar attacked Gondor, and Rohan came under attack from the Dunlendings. Initially, both kingdoms were under attack, and neither could help the other. Once the Corsairs attacking Gondor had been defeated, Beren sent a force under the command of his son Beregond north to the aid of Rohan and its war with the Dunlendings. In TA 2759, Saruman suddenly appeared and requested leave to dwell in Isengard, Beren gladly gave the Keys of Orthanc to Saruman and appointed him Warden answerable only to the Steward, because he believed Saruman could help both Gondor and Rohan recover from the effects of the Long Winter.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: In the thirtieth year of Beregond's stewardship in TA 2793, Middle-earth saw the beginning of the six year War of the Dwarves and Orcs that culminated in the Battle of Azanulbizar in TA 2799. Following that defeat many Orcs sought to take refuge in the safety of the White Mountains. The Men of Gondor led by Beregond slew many Orcs that attempted to establish themselves in the mountains, and prevented the Orcs from establishing large scale settlements and strongholds.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Belecthor was born in TA 2752 and was the only child of Beregond. When his father died in TA 2811, Belecthor succeeded him as the twenty-first Ruling Steward. Belecthor continued his father's campaigns against the Corsairs of Umbar and the Orcs. Belecthor died in TA 2872 at the age of 120 years old after a rule of sixty-one years. When he died, the White Tree of Gondor withered and died, and no sapling or seedling was found to replace it. So the withered tree was left standing until the return of the king.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Thorondir was born in TA 2782 and was the son of Belecthor II. When Belecthor passed away in TA 2872 the White Tree of Gondor also withered and died. Thorondir succeeded his father as the twenty-second Ruling Steward and decided to leave the dead tree standing until the King returned, as no seedling could be found.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: In TA 2885 Túrin fought the Haradrim at the Battle of the Crossings of Poros in South Ithilien with the aid of a contingent of Rohirrim led by Prince Folcred and Prince Fastred the twin sons of King Folcwine. The Haradrim were defeated but, in the course of the battle both Princes Folcred and Fastred were slain. After the victory Túrin paid King Folcwine a great weregild of gold. In TA 2901 Ithilien was attacked again by Mordor and many of the inhabitants withdrew west over the Anduin with only the hardiest of individuals remaining. Ithilien became a wilderness infested by Orcs from Mordor. In response Túrin built a number of hidden fortresses, including Henneth Annûn, as bases for the Rangers of Ithilien. The Steward also fortified the isle of Cair Andros.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Túrin II died in TA 2914 and Turgon succeeded to the Stewardship of Gondor. Turgon's rule was filled with low-level warfare but no significant events save at the end; two years before his death Sauron declared himself openly, re-occupying Mordor, rebuilding and re-fortifying Barad-dûr. Turgon died in TA 2953 at the age of ninety-eight years old after a rule of thirty-nine years and was succeeded by his son Ecthelion II. When news of Turgon's death reached Saruman, he declared himself Lord of Isengard and took de facto possession of Orthanc which he then fortified.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2886, Ecthelion was the son of Turgon. Ecthelion succeeded his father when he died in TA 2953 at the age of ninety-eight years. When news of Turgon's death reached Saruman he declared himself Lord of Isengard and took possession of Orthanc which he then fortified. Ecthelion was a Steward of great wisdom but was powerless to prevent the appropriation of Isengard and Orthanc, so he did what he could to strengthen Gondor's defences with what limited resources he possessed, and supplemented Gondor's diminished forces by encouraging outsiders and foreigners that possessed a good character to enter into the service of Gondor and Ecthelion rewarded those individuals that proved their worth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Denethor was the third child and only son of Ecthelion II. A proud and noble man, the blood of Númenor ran truer in him than it had in any man of Gondor for many years. He was described as subtle and often scornful and could perceive the thoughts of men, including those that dwelled far off, similar to Faramir; but his son was oft moved to pity, whereas Denethor was filled with disdain. It was difficult to deceive him and dangerous to try. In TA 2976, he married Finduilas of Dol Amroth, daughter of Prince Adrahil II of Dol Amroth. Together, the couple had two sons, Boromir and Faramir. A few years later, in TA 2988, Finduilas died young, leaving Denethor embittered.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Boromir was born in the year TA 2978. He was the eldest child of Denethor II, the last Ruling Steward of Gondor and his wife Find hills, and was the heir to the Stewardship. When Boromir was only ten years old, his mother died. Consequently, his father became grim and came to prefer Boromir over his brother, Faramir. Despite this fact, Boromir looked after his younger brother and they became very close. Boromir devoted himself to leading his people and fought in the battle for the eastern part of Osgiliath in TA 3018. He, his brother, and two others were the only survivors of the unit that held the bridge until its destruction; they had to swim the River Anduin to reach safety.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f25b0c] via-[#ffff06] to-[#f25b0c]

lotr_info.info: Adrahil was born sometime before TA 1944 and was of traceable Númenórean lineage. He served King Ondoher of Gondor as a general during the Wars of the Wainriders in the year 1944. Adrahil was descended from a Númenórean noble house that settled in Belfalas in the Second Age. Because of this, it is assumed he was an ancestor of Imrazôr, Galador and the Princes of Dol Amroth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: According to the legends of Dol Amroth, he lived at the end of the second millennium of the Third Age. He was referred to throughout his life as The Númenórean and was always believed to have wedded the Elf-maid Mithrellas, a traveling companion of Nimrodel. They had a son named Galador who was the first Prince of Dol Amroth. They also had a daughter, Gilmith.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: According to legend, Galador was the Half-elven son of Imrazôr the Númenórean and the Elf-maid Mithrellas. Following the drowning of Amroth, the seat of the Princes of Belfalas was renamed in his honour. Galador founded Dol Amroth and became its first Prince, his ancestors having held the title 'Prince' since the time of Elendil and ruling Belfalas at least as long.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Gilmith was the Half-elven daughter of Imrazôr, a man of Númenórean descent; and Mithrellas, a Silvan Elf-maiden who accompanied Nimrodel before getting lost. Imrazôr took Mithrellas in, and they married and had two children, Gilmith and Galador. Mithrellas later ran away and was never seen again. Gilmith's brother Galador would become the first Prince of Dol Amroth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Aglahad was the nineteenth Prince of Dol Amroth. No information is provided regarding Aglahad's life. His son Angelimir succeeded him in TA 2932 as the twentieth Prince of Dol Amroth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Angelimir was the son of Aglahad. Little to nothing is known of his life or reign. He married and had a son named Adrahil who succeeded him.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Adrahil was the only son of Angelimir. He succeeded his father in TA 2977. He was the father of Ivriniel, Finduilas, and the famed Prince Imrahil. He reigned for thirty-three years, dying in TA 3010.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2922 of the late-Third Age, Morwen Steelsheen was considerably taller than most of the Men in Middle-earth due to her Dúnedain heritage, a trait that was said to be inherited by a number of her descendants. Morwen lived in Belfalas, of the Prince of Dol Amroth's kin, she was called Steelsheen due to her beauty, grace and pride.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: On March 9, TA 3019, Prince Imrahil led a company of Swan Knights and 700 men at arms to Minas Tirith to help defend the city. Prince Imrahil led the sortie that rode to the aid of Faramir and the rear-guard who were retreating from Osgiliath when the forces of Sauron overran the Pelennor Fields on March 13. Gandalf rode with them, and the Winged Nazgûl fled before the Gandalf's light. The Knights of Dol Amroth rescued Faramir from the Southrons but he was poisoned, and Imrahil carried his nephew back to Minas Tirith on his horse. Gandalf then took command of the besieged city, and Prince Imrahil assisted him because Denethor, in his madness retreated to the White Tower with his dying son, paying no further attention to the city's defense.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Finduilas of Dol Amroth was the daughter of Prince Adrahil II, and had an older sister Ivriniel in addition to her brother Imrahil. In TA 2976 of the Third Age, she married the much older Denethor, son of Ecthelion II the heir to the Stewardship of Gondor. Finduilas was described as 'a lady of great beauty and gentle heart. Denethor loved her, in his fashion, more dearly than any other, unless it were the elder of the sons that she bore him. But it seemed to men that she withered in the guarded city, as a flower of the seaward vales set upon a barren rock. The shadow in the east filled her with horror, and she turned her eyes ever south to the sea that she missed.'
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Ivriniel was a noble woman of the principality of Dol Amroth in Gondor. Ivriniel was the sister of Finduilas and Imrahil, who was the Prince of Dol Amroth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Elphir was the son of Prince Imrahil, and was born in TA 2987. He had two brothers, Erchirion and Amrothos, and one sister, Lothíriel. He was a grown man during the War of the Ring but his service in it is unknown. His wife's name is also unknown, but he was known to have a son named Alphros who would become the twenty-fourth Prince of Dol Amroth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: Lothíriel was the wife of King Éomer of Rohan. Lothíriel was the daughter of Prince Imrahil of Dol Amroth; her mother's name is not known. Lothíriel was born in TA 2999. She had three older brothers: Elphir, Erchirion, and Amrothos. She was Boromir and Faramir's cousin. Lothíriel married Éomer, King of Rohan, in TA 3021 They had at least one son named Elfwine the Fair, who became the nineteenth King of Rohan on the death of his father in the year 63 of the Fourth Age.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: The son of Elphir, Alphros was a child during the War of the Ring. When Aragorn II Elessar became King of the Reunited Kingdom, Alphros succeeded his father as Prince of Dol Amroth and served under Aragorn until he would die in FO 95.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#fd7afe] via-[#abcae9] to-[#fd7afe]

lotr_info.info: The realm of Vidugavia was located between the eastern edge of Greenwood the Great and the river River Running. He was the ancestor of the Lords of the Éothéod and the Kings of Rohan. Although some Northmen had not remained faithful to Gondor in its war with the Easterlings, the powerful 'Regent of the realm' of Gondor, Minalcar, sought an alliance with the Northmen nonetheless. He came to favor Vidugavia to whom he regarded the most faithful and reliable, and was Gondor's ally in the war with the Easterlings.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: Vidumavi married the heir to Gondor's throne, Prince Valacar, when he was on a diplomatic mission to Rhovanion after the year TA 1250. The Dúnedain of Gondor feared that a shorter-lived bloodline would weaken Gondor's royal line. In TA 1255, she bore Valacar a son and heir, the future King Eldacar. Because of Eldacar's short-lived Northman mother, many of the Dúnedain and Men of Gondor were unwilling to accept him as king. This led to the disastrous Kin-strife eighty-eight years later in TA 1432.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#fffeff]

lotr_info.info: Marhari was a Northman noble of Rhovanion and a descendant of King Vidugavia. In TA 1856, Marhari and King Narmacil II of Gondor led a combined force of Men from Gondor and Men from Rhovanion into the disastrous Battle of the Plains where they were both slain, with Marhari slain in the rearguard. The Wainriders then enslaved the people of Vidugavia's realm. His son Marhwini led a group of survivors to refuge in the Vales of Anduin, where they founded a colony and became the Éothéod, the ancestors of the Rohirrim.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: Marhwini was the first lord of the people who became known as the Éothéod, later the Rohirrim. Marhwini was the son of Marhari, who led a remnant of Northmen from Rhovanion to battle alongside Gondor to stop the advance of the Wainriders years earlier. Through Marhari his father, he was also a direct descendant of Vidugavia, 'King of Rhovanion'. Marhwini's father Marhari first aligned his people with Gondor in a fight with the Wainriders called the Battle of the Plains. In that conflict, King Narmacil II of Gondor was slain, as was Marhari. Marhwini then led a remnant of what remained of the Northmen to the vales of Anduin, where they mixed with fugitives escaped from the east. These people would come to be known as the Éothéod, they were the culture that would become the Rohirrim.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: Forthwini was the son of Marhwini and second Lord of the Éothéod. Like his father before him, Forthwini lived in troubled times with all the lands east of the Misty Mountains still in danger of invasion from the Easterling Wainriders. As their home in the plains of Rhovanion had been occupied in the century before, the remaining free Northmen lived in the plains south of Mirkwood and came to be called the Éothéod.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: Frumgar was the third Lord of the Éothéod and the ancestor of Eorl the Young. Frumgar led his people north from the middle Vales of Anduin in a migration to the land between the rivers Langwell and Greylin after the overthrow of Angmar, to escape the ever increasing dangers of their former home, which was close to Dol Guldur.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: Fram and his people lived in the far northern part of Wilderland, just below the Grey Mountains in the mid-Third Age. He was most famous for slaying the dragon Scatha in TA 2000. After he slew Scatha, he claimed the dragon's treasure horde, which the Dwarves believed rightfully belonged to them. Knowing this, he sent back to them a necklace made from the teeth of Scatha along with this message: 'Jewels such as these you will not find in your treasuries, for they are hard to come by.' However, the Dwarves found this insulting. The outcome of his fate is uncertain, though it is believed that he may have been slain out of revenge by the Dwarves for the insult.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: During his lordship, the Éothéod once again increased in number and were becoming constrained in the small land in which they lived. He lived in Framsburg between the rivers Greylin and Langwell. He was probably a descendant of the famed Fram, the Dragon-Slayer. Léod was killed trying to tame the horse Felaróf. Eorl later captured Felaróf and his species, the Mearas, became bound to his descendants as a weregild for Léod's death.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#ffc606] via-[#fff118] to-[#d5b838]

lotr_info.info: Eorl was the last Lord of the Éothéod and the first King of Rohan. He was the founder of the House of Eorl, the royal dynasty which ruled Rohan. Eorl was born in TA 2485. His father was Léod, the leader of the people called the Éothéod who lived in the far north near the source of the Anduin. In TA 2501 when Eorl was sixteen years old, Léod was killed by a wild horse that he had tried to tame; for this act the horse was called Mansbane by the Éothéod. Eorl hunted the horse and rather than kill him required that the horse serve him and surrender his freedom as a Weregild. The horse submitted and Eorl renamed him Felaróf. Felaróf became Eorl's steed and was the father of the Mearas, who were the steeds of Eorl's descendants. It was also said that Felaróf would not permit any other man to ride him.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Brego was born in TA 2512, the only child of Eorl the Young. When Eorl was slain in battle in TA 2545, Brego became King of Rohan. During his rule, the settling of the Éothéod in Rohan continued, and Brego defended the borders of Rohan against their enemies (the Dunlendings and Easterlings). Brego built the Golden Hall of Meduseld, and made Edoras the capital of Rohan. Construction of the Golden Hall was completed in TA 2569.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Aldor was born in TA 2544 and was the second son of King Brego. He became his father's heir after his elder brother, Baldor, was lost attempting to pass through the Paths of the Dead. King Brego died of grief shortly afterwards in TA 2570, and Aldor succeeded him at the age of twenty-six. His rule was considered a golden age for Rohan. The Wildmen of Dunland were driven back over the Gap of Rohan, and the numbers of the Rohirrim increased. Under his rule, Dunharrow was established as a refuge and the valleys of Rohan were colonized.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Eofor was a Prince of Rohan and the first Lord of Aldburg, the third son of Brego, who was the second King of Rohan. Éofor was born sometime around TA 2544 after his older brother Aldor. He was the direct ancestor of Éomund, the father of Éomer, who founded the third line of Eorl, and Éowyn. He lived in the old fortress of Aldburg with his family, founding a long line of noblemen who ruled the Eastfold.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Baldor, also known as Baldor the Hapless, was the oldest son of Brego, second Lord of the Mark, and brother of Aldor, third Lord of the Mark. He was said to have passed along the Paths of the Dead, through the Dark Door under Dwimorberg. Théoden said 'A rash vow he spoke, as he drained the horn at the feast which Brego made to hallow new-built Meduseld, and he never came to the high seat of which he was the heir'.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2570, Fréa was the youngest child and only son of Aldor the Old. After the death of his father in TA 2645, he succeeded as the King of Rohan. He ruled for fourteen years until his death in TA 2659, at the age of eighty-nine, and was followed by his son Fréawine.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Fréawine was born in TA 2594 and was the son of Fréa. He lived during the long reign of his grandfather, Aldor and was himself already a grandfather when Aldor died in TA 2645. When his father became king, Fréawine became the heir to the throne of Rohan. After Fréa's death, Fréawine became the King of Rohan and ruled uneventfully for twenty-one years until his death at the age of eighty-six in TA 2680. Fréawine was succeeded by his son, Goldwine.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2619, Goldwine was the son of Fréawine. He was born during the reign of his great-grandfather, Aldor the Old. Goldwine was aged twenty-six, and already a father, when Aldor finally died in TA 2645. The crown passed to his grandfather Fréa. Fourteen years later, in TA 2659, his father Fréawine became King of Rohan when he was forty. Goldwine ascended the throne of Rohan in TA 2680 at the age of sixty-one. By the time Goldwine came to the throne he was already a grandfather.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Déor was the seventh King of Rohan. Born in TA 2644, Déor was the son of Goldwine. Déor was born during the reign of his great-great-grandfather Aldor the Old.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Freca was a local lord of Rohan who was known for having been killed by King Helm Hammerhand, indirectly sparking a conflict between Rohan and the Dunlendings.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Gram was born in TA 2668 to his father, King Déor, and his unnamed wife. Gram became king at the age of fifty when Déor died in TA 2718. His reign was one of war with the Dunlendings, who continued to raid Rohan from the fortress of Isengard which they controlled. He died in TA 2741 at the age of seventy-three, after twenty-three years of open warfare, and was succeeded by his son Helm Hammerhand, who continued the struggle.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Wulf was a Dunlending lord who, for a short period of time during the War between Rohan and Dunland, ruled Rohan. Wulf was the son of Freca, a Rohirrim lord of Dunlending heritage, who tried to force a wedding between Wulf and the daughter of King Helm Hammerhand. Following Freca's death at the hands of Helm, Wulf and the rest of Freca's kinsmen were declared enemies of Rohan and fled the kingdom. Welcomed with open arms by the Wild Men of Dunland, he became their leader and allied himself with the Easterlings, Haradrim and Corsairs of Umbar - who were in turn stirred up by Sauron.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Helm was the ninth King of Rohan, and the last of the first line of its Kings. His rule was plagued by war with Dunlendings that attempted to usurp his rule of Rohan. Helm was born in TA 2691 to the royal House of Eorl that had ruled Rohan since TA 2510, during the reign of his great-grandfather, King Goldwine, sixth King of Rohan. Helm was the son of Prince Gram, the grandson of King Goldwine as son of Crown Prince Déor. When Helm was a young boy in TA 2699, the elderly King Goldwine died at the age of 80 after a long, peaceful reign, and the Crown Prince, aged 55, succeeded him as seventh King of Rohan. With King Déor's ascension, Helm's father Gram become the new Crown Prince, while Helm himself became second in line to the throne as grandson of the reigning monarch.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Hild was a princess of Rohan. She was the daughter of King Gram, eighth King of Rohan, and the sister of Helm Hammerhand, ninth King of Rohan. She was the mother of Fréaláf, who became the first King of Rohan in the second line.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Háma was born around TA 2719, a year after the death of his great-grandfather King Déor, the seventh King of Rohan, during the reign of his grandfather King Gram, the eighth King of Rohan. He was the second son of the King's eldest son Helm and his unnamed wife; he had one unnamed sister and an older brother named Haleth. Háma would spend the first twenty-two years of his life growing up in the court of his grandfather King Gram, who ruled over a time of increasing conflict with the Dunlendings. Gram died in TA 2741, and Helm succeeded him as king. Háma would by now be second in line to the throne, as second son of the new king.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Haleth was born sometime around TA 2716, during the last years of the reign of his great-grandfather King Déor, the seventh King of Rohan. He would be the eldest son of Prince Helm Hammerhand and his unnamed wife, and would later have a sister, whose name is unknown, as well as a younger brother named Háma. His father Helm was the son of Gram, son and heir apparent to the reigning King Déor. When Haleth was a baby in TA 2718 his great-grandfather King Déor, now an old man at seventy-four, died after a nineteen-year reign spent fighting the Dunlendings and was succeeded by Haleth's grandfather Gram, who became the eighth king of Rohan.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Fréaláf Hildeson was the tenth King of Rohan, and the first king of the second line. Fréaláf was born in TA 2726 and was the son of the noblewoman Hild, the sister of Helm Hammerhand and an unnamed father. When Rohan was invaded by the Dunlendings led by Wulf, he and other survivors fled towards the refuges in Dunharrow. It was from there that Fréaláf planned an attack to regain Edoras.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2752, Brytta was the son of Fréaláf Hildeson. He became king at the age of forty-six when his father died in TA 2798. During his reign, Rohan was still recovering from its war with the Dunlendings, and hostilities remained at the western borders. Brytta possessed a generous nature and was always willing to help those in need, because of his generous and kind spirit he earned the epithet Léofa, which means Beloved, in the Rohanese tongue. Aside from the troubles with the Dunlendings his rule saw a new trouble, as the War of the Dwarves and Orcs caused great numbers of Orcs to flee from the Misty Mountains, the Orcs sought to make strongholds and refuges in the White Mountains south of Rohan.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Walda was born in TA 2780 and was the son of Brytta Léofa. As Prince of Rohan, he served in the army and helped to defend the realm from the Orcs that tried to invade Rohan during King Brytta's reign. After his father's death in TA 2842, Walda succeeded to the throne at the age of sixty-two. Some Orcs remained in Rohan, however; and nine years later after his succession in TA 2851, Walda was killed during an Orc attack in Dunharrow. His son Folca then became King and avenged his death.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2804, Folca was the son of Walda. He became King of Rohan in TA 2851 at the age of forty-seven, after his father was killed by an Orc. When his father was slain, Folca, a passionate hunter, swore an oath to hunt no animal while an Orc was left within the borders of Rohan. It took Folca thirteen years to hunt down and destroy all the remaining Orcs, avenging the murder of his father and clearing the lands of Rohan of the threat posed by the Orcs.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Folcwine was born in TA 2830 to King Folca. He succeeded to the throne upon his father's death in TA 2864, at the age of thirty-four. During his reign the West-march was reconquered from the Dunlendings and Rohan finally recovered from the effects of the wars of the Long Winter.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Born in TA 2870, Fengel was the youngest child and only surviving son of Folcwine. In TA 2885, when Fengel was fifteen, his elder brothers Folcred and Fastred were killed during the Battle of the Crossings of Poros. With the deaths of his older brothers, Fengel automatically became heir to the Kingship of Rohan and Lordship of the Riddermark.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Folcred was one of the twin sons of King Folcwine. Folcred was the twin brother of Fastred. Both went to the aid of Gondor when Ithilien was invaded by the Haradrim in TA 2885, and were slain in the Battle of the Crossings of Poros. Túrin II, the Steward of Gondor, thereafter sent a weregild of gold to their father. Both brothers were buried in a mound raised over them at the crossings named Haudh in Gwanûr.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Fastred was a man of Rohan and one of the twin sons of King Folcwine, brother of Folcred. He had a younger brother Fengel and an unnamed sister. Fastred was killed in the Battle of the Crossings of Poros when he and his brother led an army to aid Gondor against the Haradrim. The enemy was defeated, but both twins were slain in the battle. Fastred and his brother were buried near where they fell, in a mound named Haudh in Gwanûr.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Gálmód was a Man of Rohan and the father of Gríma Wormtongue. Because nothing is known of Gálmód, it is not clear whether he had held a high position in Rohan, nor was it known whether he was deceased by the time his son advised the king. He was known by Gandalf, so he might of had some meeting with the wizard.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Thengel was the only son of Fengel, the fifteenth King of Rohan. He left the realm in his youth and went to live in Gondor, winning honour in the service of the Steward Turgon. Eventually he met and married Morwen Steelsheen of Lossarnach, and he lived with her there for a while. After Fengel died in TA 2953, Thengel was called upon to return to Rohan, which he reluctantly did and succeeded his father as King of Rohan. During his reign Saruman began to trouble the borders of Rohan with raids, although he did not become known as the culprit until the War of the Ring decades later.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Théoden was the only son of Thengel, and became king after the death of his father in TA 2980. Théoden spoke Sindarin and Westron more often than Rohanese, due to the influence of his father, and spent a part of his youth growing up in the mountain vales of Gondor, his mother's homeland. His sister Théodwyn lived with him in Edoras, and after she and her husband both died he adopted her children Éomer and Éowyn as his own. He had a son Théodred, whose mother, Elfhild, died at childbirth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Théodwyn of Rohan was the mother of Éomer and Éowyn. The sister of King Théoden and youngest child of Thengel and Morwen Steelsheen, she married Éomund of Eastfold in TA 2989. Her son Éomer was born in TA 2991, and her daughter Éowyn in TA 2995. Éomund was slain in TA 3002. Not long afterward, Théodwyn died of illness, and Théoden raised her two children.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Gríma, called Wormtongue, was the chief counsellor at the court of King Théoden of Rohan. Bought by the corrupted Wizard Saruman, Gríma became his mole in the Edoras court and worked to weaken the Rohirrim. When his treachery was exposed, Gríma fled to Isengard and ended up entrapped in Orthanc with Saruman.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Éomund was the First Marshal of the Mark of Rohan under King Théoden in the years leading up to the War of the Ring. He was also the last Lord of Aldburg, the father of Éomer and Éowyn, and the husband of Théodwyn, sister of Théoden. Éomund was a distant descendant of Éofor, the first Lord of Aldburg, and youngest of the sons of Brego, who was the son of Eorl.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Elfhild was a woman of Rohan, the wife of Théoden and mother of Théodred. Nothing else is told about Elfhild's life except that after her death, Théoden never remarried. She died in childbirth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Erkenbrand was a warrior of Rohan during the War of the Ring. He was the Lord of the Westfold, commanding the Deeping-coomb and much other land, if not the rest of the region. This made him also the chief lord in the West-mark.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Éomer, born in TA 2991, of the House of Eorl, was the son of Éomund, the Lord of Aldburg and descendant of Éofor, and of Théodwyn, sister of King Théoden. In TA 3002, when Éomer was eleven, Éomund was slain in battle with Orcs. Théodwyn died of grief shortly afterward. Éomund also had a daughter named Éowyn, Éomer's sister. After they were orphaned Théoden adopted them as his own children.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Éowyn was a shieldmaiden of Rohan, daughter of Éomund and Théodwyn, younger sister of Éomer and niece of King Théoden. After the War of the Ring, she married Faramir and had one son with him, Elboron. Éowyn was the second child of Éomund and Théodwyn. Like her brother Éomer, she was related to King Théoden through their mother, the King's sister. Her father was slain and her mother died of illness in TA 3002. Afterwards, Théoden took Éomer and Éowyn in his household and raised them as his children.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Théodred's mother Elfhild died giving birth to him. During the War of the Ring, Prince Théodred was the Second Marshal of Rohan and commanded western Rohan. In the First Battle of the Fords of Isen he set Grimbold in command with fifty dismounted Riders, while Théodred himself manned the eyot in the centre of the Fords, to cover Grimbold if he was driven back. Amidst the battle Théodred was slain by an Orc-man and his body was defended by the marshal Grimbold. When Elfhelm arrived with reinforcements he found Grimbold fighting two axemen for Théodred's body. His body was buried where he fell, on the fortified eyot in the middle of the Fords of Isen.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Dúnhere was a captain of riders and the Lord of Harrowdale in the White Mountains. During the War of the Ring, Dúnhere did not accompany Gandalf and Erkenbrand to the Battle of the Hornburg; instead, they sent him to oversee the muster of the Rohirrim in his native Harrowdale. Several days later, he met Théoden upon his arrival at Harrowdale. He was also present in the King's pavilion at Dunharrow in a council concerning the Muster of Rohan. At the Battle of the Pelennor Fields, Dúnhere was slain along with many heroes. He was remembered in the Song of the Mounds of Mundburg.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Elfwine was the first son of King Éomer and Lothíriel, the daughter of Prince Imrahil of Dol Amroth. As Elfwine ruled in the Fourth Age after the Red Book of Westmarch had been written, not much is known about him or his deeds as ruler of Rohan, but he kept the ancient Oath of Eorl, maintaining the alliance of Rohan and Gondor. He became king in the year FO 63 upon his father's death and ruled long after. Nothing further of his life is known. He was said to have a striking resemblance to his maternal grandfather, Imrahil, the well-known Prince of Dol Amroth.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-gradient-to-r from-[#f5900c] via-[#fff118] to-[#f5900c]

lotr_info.info: Beorn was a Northman, skin-changer, and chieftain of the Beornings who lived in the upper Vales of Anduin between Mirkwood and the Misty Mountains. He aided Thorin and Company during their Quest of Erebor. His kin lived in that region during the last centuries of the Third Age, guarding the Ford of Carrock from the Northern Orcs and the Wargs. He was the father of Grimbeorn the Old.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Grimbeorn's date of birth is unknown, but it likely followed the Battle of Five Armies in the year TA 2941. By the time of the War of the Ring, Grimbeorn ruled over the Vales of Anduin, presumably becoming chieftain of the Beornings after his father's death. As chieftain, he kept the High Pass and the Ford of Carrock free from Orcs and Wolves, though Glóin commented to Frodo Baggins shortly before the Council of Elrond that his 'tolls are high' and he was 'not over fond of Dwarves.'
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#ffca97]

lotr_info.info: Faramir was born in the year TA 2983 to Denethor II and Finduilas, daughter of Adrahil of Dol Amroth. The following year, his grandfather Ecthelion II died and his father, Denethor, succeeded him as the Ruling Steward of Gondor. When Faramir was five years old, Finduilas died. Her death caused Denethor to become detached from his family. The relationship between Faramir and Boromir, who was five years older, grew much closer and greater in love. Although the siblings were very similar in appearance with their dark hair and grey eyes, it was not so in personality. Boromir was defined to be the more daring one, as well as the more fearless and strong warrior. Faramir’s boldness was incorrectly judged less due to his gentle nature and love of lore and music. Despite the obvious way that Denethor favored Boromir over Faramir, and their significant differences in personality, there was never any jealousy or rivalry between the brothers. Boromir always protected and helped Faramir, and Faramir in turn greatly admired his older brother.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#00e127]

lotr_info.info: Elboron was born sometime after the War of the Ring. He succeeded his father Faramir as Prince of Ithilien, Lord of Emyn Arnen, and the Steward of Gondor, after the death of his father in FO 82. It is possible that Elboron was the father of Barahir, the grandson of Faramir and author of The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#00e127]

lotr_info.info: Barahir lived in the second century of the Fourth Age, possibly during the threat of the New Shadow in Gondor. He was also the author of The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen. Nothing else of his life is known. Except for his grandparents Faramir and Éowyn, the details of Barahir's descent are uncertain. In The Heirs of Elendil (the ultimate basis for much of Appendix A), there is a single mention of a son of Faramir - apparently his only child - named Elboron. It is widely speculated that this Elboron was Barahir's father. This would in turn presumably see Barahir inheriting the titles of Steward of Gondor and Prince of Ithilien, though it should be emphasized that none of this is explicitly stated by Tolkien.
lotr_info.color_bg: border-[#3eb6d8] border-2 bg-[#00e127]

lotr_info.info: Born at an unknown date, Girion became the Lord of Dale and ruled the city peacefully under the Dwarves of Erebor. However, in the year TA 2770, he was killed when the dragon Smaug destroyed Dale and the neighboring Dwarven realm of Erebor. However, his wife (name unknown) and son escaped.
